name: madeline campbell • happiest sober
bio:
your sobriety hype girl ✨
sober living • sober travel • sober swiftie
🎙 @happiestsoberpodcast
👇🏻 travel Croatia sober with me!
🇨🇦 toronto / denver

social_posts.post_text:
Now that I’m sober, I get to wake up thinking about this moment, this morning, this day ahead, rather than waking up in a state of anxiety and playing detective on what happened last night. 

Currently drinking my morning coffee, enjoying the sunshine, and reveling in how great that is. 🥰☕️ Happy Thursday, sober fam! #happiestsober

We’re on day 2 of December, which means that we’re officially into the holiday season (or as our queen @taylorswift would say, ‘tis the damn season). 

So here are some reminders for anyone who needs them:
• You do not need alcohol to get through the holiday season.
• If this is a really happy time of year for you, alcohol won’t enhance it. It will just dim it.
• If this is a really hard time of year for you, alcohol won’t make it better. It will just magnify those emotions.
• Holidays & celebrations should be remembered.
• If you need to leave a party early (or not go at all this year), that’s okay. Put your needs & your sobriety first.
• Every single night that you don’t drink, you will wake up in the morning so grateful to yourself for it.
• People aren’t entitled to hear your story of why you’re not drinking if you aren’t comfortable sharing it.
• Christmas lights are so much prettier when you’re clear-minded to take them in.
• Being present is the best present you could give yourself. And so is feeling proud of who you are.
• Just because it’s hard, doesn’t mean it’s impossible. You can do this.

My first sober Christmas was so hard. I spent the entire evening contemplating whether or not I was going to cave and drink. 

This year is my third. I’m heading off to a Christmas party with family friends tonight, and the fact that I won’t be drinking has barely even crossed my mind.

It. Gets. Easier. And we’re in this together, sober fam ❤️ #happiestsober

Happy Saturday sober fam! I’ve seen @sobergirlsociety (and other pages!) do this and I think it’s such a great & fun idea, so let’s do it! 👇🏻

HOW IT WORKS:
-Check the comments to see if someone has already dropped your location.
-If not, then comment your city below! (be specific and include your country as well)
-Connect with your local sober people in the comments and make some sober friendsssss ✨

The holidays can feel like an especially isolating time for many of us, and making sober connections in this community is SO helpful on this journey. So don’t be afraid to reach out to someone and say hi!! You don’t have to do this alone 💕 #happiestsober

Cheers to an alcohol-free Sunday, sober fam!

As we head into the holidays, here’s your reminder that you don’t need alcohol in your glass to feel festive & celebratory and to enjoy this time of year.

And if you want to cheers with something extra special & ✨fancy✨ in your glass at your next holiday party, there are so many amazing alcohol-free options, like this @teetotalerwines red which I loveeee ♥️

I’m so ready to enjoy this holiday season with a clear mind, a clear conscience, and clear memories of all of it. Alcohol-free wine cheers to that! 🍷 #happiestsober #ad
Who would’ve thought?! ✨ #happiestsober
Just dropping in to remind you how amazing you are for being here 💅🏻✨  #happiestsober

No matter how many times I felt tempted to drink again after I quit, the one thing I could always come back to was knowing that I don’t ever want to feel that low again. 

The anxiety. The blackouts. The shame. The embarrassment. The regrets. 

We never have to feel that way again. All we have to do is not drink. 

I’ve been able to stay sober by reminding myself as many times as I need to that drinking is never worth the level of suffering I’d feel tomorrow. 

After a decade of being stuck on that hamster wheel, getting to wake up with peace of mind is something I never want to take for granted. 🤍 #happiestsober

So I thought maybe after I passed 2 years, I would stop celebrating monthly milestones.

BUT it was impossible not to notice that today is the 8th of the month after 2 years of always paying attention & celebrating on the 8th. 😂

And honestly, life is short and we’re doing a super cool thing. So I’m just gonna keep celebrating milestones as long as I keep noticing the date. 🥰✨

Halfway to 50 months and that’s pretty wild! 💃🏼

And just a reminder that everyone with any sober time under their belt started off with a day 1 that felt impossible. But all those days of taking it one day at a time eventually add up.

So no matter where you’re at on your journey, and no matter how impossible it feels, keep going. ♥️ #happiestsober

Today feels like the perfect time to repost these collages of hangxiety-fuelled texts I sent in my drinking days.

Some of the worst mornings I’ve had after drinking were during my last holiday season before I got sober (and that’s when some of these texts are from).

I know a lot of you are probably heading to holiday parties tonight/this weekend, so let this be your reminder of how you don’t want to feel tomorrow.

No matter how tempting it might feel when other people start drinking around you, you know what’s waiting for you in the morning if you drink.

Staying sober - no matter how uncomfortable it might feel in the moment - is so beyond worth the payoff when you get to wake up tomorrow with crystal clear memories, a clear conscience, and no hangover. 

You don’t want to have to send texts like these this holiday season. Let that be your motivator. You can do this and I’m cheering you on. ❤️ #happiestsober

Went to my second wedding sober yesterday! 🫶🏻

When I was walking from the ceremony to the reception, it dawned on me that in my drinking days, I would have had SUCH a sense of urgency right about then to get a glass of wine in my hand, stat. 

It’s a pretty great feeling to be free of that need to get booze in me before I can enjoy myself, relax, have fun, etc.

I sipped cranberry gingerales, waters, and coffees. I enjoyed every bite of my dinner & dessert. I had clear-minded conversations that I remember clearly today. I danced. I got to be fully present for my cousin’s special day.

The idea of tackling weddings without drinking felt soooo daunting (and downright depressing) when I first got sober. But honestly now I think they’re my favourite 💕 #happiestsober

You’re doing such a hard thing and I’m so proud of you for being here & trying. Be kind to yourself, remember that this is a process, let slips be a learning experience, and keep. going. ♥️ #happiestsober
It once felt impossible to every single one of us. But I promise it’s not impossible for you. You can do this, and amazing things are in store for you when you do 🤍✨ #happiestsober

Remember all the times you woke up in physical & mental agony after drinking and said to yourself “never again”? Give that gift to yourself. ♥️

The beauty of it is that you don’t actually have to decide it’s forever. You just have to decide not to drink today. And then wake up and do the same tomorrow. But you can worry about tomorrow when it gets here.

Just stay sober today. All we have is this day in front of us.

All the days of “I’m not drinking today” will add up, and slowly but surely your life will transform in the best possible way. You can do this. 💫 #happiestsober

One of the most profound shifts for me when I got sober was the amount of pride I felt in myself for it.

With every single day that passed, I woke up feeling so. damn. proud. of myself for the fact that I didn’t drink.

And I still feel that way to this day! My sobriety is something I feel so proud of, and it is something that should be so celebrated by every single one of us!

Not drinking is such a huge accomplishment on its own. But every single thing we tackle sober is a freakin WIN.

Whether that’s just getting through the day without drinking, or trying something new, or doing something that scares you, or being kinder to yourself, or sitting with discomfort, or practicing boundaries, or letting yourself rest, or noticing an inner shift. Every single thing in sobriety is worth celebrating.

So I want to give you space today to celebrate yourselves! ✨ Share a win with me in the comments & tell me something that’s made you feel proud of yourself recently. It could be literally ANYTHING - nothing is too small! I am here for allllll of it.

Throw being humble out the window right now 😂 and celebrate the hell out of yourself! You deserve it, and I want to cheer you on! 👇🏻🎉💖 #happiestsober
Just think of all the time you’re getting back this weekend now that you won’t be wasting any time with hangovers ✨ #happiestsober

#BeTheBestHost this holiday season with @above.cocktails ✨

We all know what it feels like to go to a party that doesn’t have non-alcoholic drink options apart from, well, water 😬

Feeling included as a sober person is everythingggg, especially during the holidays, which can already be a tough time to navigate without alcohol!

So stock up on some delicious non-alcoholic options for your next holiday party, and let’s have some booze-free fun that we’ll remember tomorrow! ♥️ #happiestsober #ad

Just dropping in with a reminder that alcohol is a depressant, and you absolutely do not need it to have fun this weekend, or to celebrate the holidays, or to connect with others, or to let loose. And you most definitely don’t need it to be happy. 💕

Nothing connects us back to our authentic inner sense of joy like kicking booze to the curb and discovering it in ourselves again. 

It’s hard at first, and it’s okay if it takes you a while to find it. But I promise you that it’s so worth it. 

Happy Saturday sober fam! I’m cheering you on for an alcohol-free, hangover-free weekend ✨ #happiestsober
A sober girl & her Saturday night mocktail: a love story 🫶🏻✨ #happiestsober

Let this Christmas be one that you actually remember clearly, and don’t have any shame attached to from your drinking.

If you’re struggling with the holidays this year, drinking won’t make that better. Any temporary relief you feel from drinking will backfire, and those negative feelings will be magnified tomorrow. We can survive discomfort & feelings don’t last forever.

If you’re feeling happy about this time of year, you don’t need alcohol to celebrate those happy feelings. You aren’t missing out on the fun by not drinking. What you ARE missing out on by not drinking is waking up full of regrets, and I will gladly take a pass on that every time.

The best gift we can give ourselves is being fully present for this time of year and letting ourselves feel the full range of our emotions. And there is literally NO better feeling than waking up hangover-free and hangxiety-free the day after a holiday.

Sending so much love to every single one of you this week. Even if it’s hard, it doesn’t mean you can’t do it. We’re in this together, sober fam, and we’ve got this ♥️ #happiestsober

Being sober means always having something to be grateful for. And when we’re living in this booze-obsessed world, staying connected to sober gratitude is everythinggg.

Here are 5 things I can feel grateful for this morning because of my sobriety:
1. I didn’t wake up with any drunk texts on my phone.
2. I get to enjoy my morning coffee with peace of mind, and without the side of anxiety, guilt, shame, headache, and nausea that came along with drinking.
3. Christmas is this weekend, and I know that I’ll be fully present for it and will remember every second of it.
4. It’s been 2+ years since I’ve had to ask someone else what I did last night. 
5. I’m always clear-minded, I fully trust myself now, and I get to wake up feeling proud of the person that I am (instead of waking up in a hungover shame spiral).

No matter how challenging sobriety can feel sometimes, there are always things to be grateful for in it. 

Even on my worst days, at least I don’t have a hangover. 🫶🏻 #happiestsober
Wednesday reminder that all feelings are allowed. And that you don’t have to drink to get through them. 🤍 #happiestsober
Seriously, just you wait ✨ #happiestsober

Happy Friday, sober fam! Just in case you haven’t heard it lately, I’m SO proud of you for being on this journey. And I’m extra proud of you for being here at this time of the year. 

Sending so much love to anyone who is finding this holiday season challenging without booze. I’ve been there, and I promise you that all the hard feelings are so worth hanging in for. 

Hard feelings don’t last forever. But the sense of pride & accomplishment you’ll feel in yourself for getting through hard times without drinking can 🫶🏻

Take it day by day, hour by hour, moment by moment if you need to. And just keep remembering that one day you’re going to thank yourself for this ♥️ #happiestsober

Merry Christmas Eve, sober fam!

Here’s your reminder that you don’t need booze in your glass to have fun tonight! I just so happened to have hot chocolate in this 🎅🏻 mug the other night, and I had a freakin blast!

You deserve a hangover-free Christmas morning. Give that gift to yourself by not drinking tonight.

You also deserve a Christmas Day that you actually remember & can look back on proudly. Give that gift to yourself tomorrow by not drinking, too.

It’s okay if it’s hard. But also, you never know how great it can be until you do it.

We’re all in this together and I’m cheering you on!

For those of you who celebrate, I hope you have a wonderful Christmas Eve! 🎄✨ #happiestsober

Good morning and Merry Christmas to all who celebrate!!! And happy happy holidays, merriest wishes for whatever it is that you’re celebrating this season!🎄♥️✨

First things first: my first sober Christmas definitely did notttt feel very merry without booze, so here’s your reminder that it’s okay if that’s where you’re at.

Even when staying sober has felt the most challenging, I could always remember that my hardest sober moment will never feel as bad as how drinking made me feel. 

By staying sober today, you’re giving yourself the best gift: a holiday you’ll actually remember, and a holiday that doesn’t have any shame & embarrassment attached to it because of alcohol.

No matter how challenging today might feel, your prize at the end of it is waking up tomorrow with crystal clear memories of the entire day, your dignity still intact, feeling SO proud of yourself, and without any of the anxiety and guilt (let alone, the hangover) that drinking brings. 

And if today is a challenge, it doesn’t mean the holidays will feel challenging without booze forever! Change is hard at first, but then it gets easier. And as we keep taking it day by day and keep sitting with our feelings, we transform ourselves & our lives from the inside out. ✨

The further along I get in my sobriety, the more grateful I feel to be fully present for days like these. Holidays feel so much more special when all their happiness & magic comes from the celebration itself and not from the wine I’m downing. 

If you’re here and you’re trying, you’re so freaking brave & strong and I’m here rooting for you. I hope you all have a wonderful and magical booze-free day ♥️ #happiestsober

PS, today I’m #merriestsober 😉

My third sober Christmas and so far it’s been the best one I’ve had in years 🥰

I’m feeling extra grateful this holiday season to be a part of such an incredible, kind, inspiring, courageous, supportive community. I’m sending so much love to each & every one of you today 💗 #happiestsober #merriestsober

The last holiday season I drank for was in 2019, and I was filled with so much anxiety, guilt, and shame in the aftermath that it pushed me to do dry January (I’d never taken a break from drinking before).

Remembering how the holidays felt 3 years ago fills me with SO much gratitude for being sober.

This was my third sober Christmas, and it’s the first one where I’ve felt completelyyy at peace with not drinking & didn’t struggle with my sobriety at all or have any FOMO.

I had an amazing day and alcohol just wasn’t even something I really thought about or wanted, even though people around me were drinking. That was once UNTHINKABLE for me. 

I say it all the time, but sobriety gets easier and easier. And it’s SO beyond worth hanging in for. Because even the times where it feels most challenging, that hangover-free morning with a clear conscience is the best victory at the end of it.

I wouldn’t trade my sobriety for anything. And I’ll never stop being thankful for the fact that I made this decision, and have stuck with it even on the hardest days. 

It’s so important for me to stay connected to how far I’ve come, because it reminds me of what I never want to go back to. I might miss drinking every once in a while, but I’ll never miss the aftermath of it. And that’s what I can always hold onto.

If you drank yesterday, be kind to yourself. Today is a new day and you can start again. This journey is not linear and almost nobody gets it perfect on the first try. Keep going. You have a whole community here rooting for you. ♥️ #happiestsober
Sobriety is the ultimate freedom 🤍 #happiestsober

Festive season is coming to an end, but that doesn’t mean we have to stop celebrating ✨OURSELVES✨ so it’s time for another support train today! 💃🏼

Drop your number of alcohol-free days in the comments, and then reply to someone else’s comment to cheer them on! 

And remember, every single day under your belt is so massive and so worth celebrating. If you’re on day 1, or if you slipped over the holidays, we’re all here to support you! There is no failure here 🫶🏻

I’ll go first: 780 days today! #happiestsober
2022 is wrapping up, and it’s the second year I can say I was sober for the whole entire thing ✨ #happiestsober
Will be soberly ✨strutting✨ into 2023 because I know I’m bringing my best, present, clear-minded, authentic, sober self into the near year. Who’s with me?! ☺️ #happiestsober

Happy New Year’s Eve, sober fam!!! I seriously get SO excited for a new year. I love love love the idea of newness & a fresh start. 

This year & last year, I started writing out a list of intentions for the new year rather than resolutions. Yesterday I spent a while writing out my 2023 intentions (the list is LONG 😆), and it got me so amped up!

Now that I’m reflecting on it, I think my love of New Years has really grown since I quit drinking. And I think such a big part of that is that I can now trust myself & my ability to follow through on my intentions. And that’s all thanks to my sobriety.

2022 is the second year where I can say I was sober for the whole entire thing. There were so many highs and so many lows but I feel like this is the year where I’ve grown more than ever. Sobriety kind of forces that out of us in the best possible way. ✨

If you’re struggling with the idea of staying sober tonight, please remember that you deserve so much better than to kick of a brand new year with a hangover & regrets. You deserve to start off the new year sober, hangover-free, clear minded, and SO proud of yourself. 

And just a reminder that whatever you do to celebrate tonight is okay & is enough. If you feel like going out, I hope you have a blast. If you feel like staying in, then I hope you enjoy every minute. 

Remember that people who are out getting drunk probably aren’t having as much fun as they’re making it seem on social media, so try not to get caught in the comparison trap. Stay focused on the life you want to create for yourself. ❤️ 

Whatever makes you happiest tonight, do that. And let that be our mission going into this next year as well: to do whatever makes us happiest. And one thing I know for damn sure is that life’s happiest when I’m sober 🥰

2023, let’s do this! I’ve got a good feeling about this one ✨ #happiestsober

Oh hiii 2023 & hello Dry Jan! After the craziness of the holidays, January is the perfect time to reset & do something kind for ourselves. And one of the absolute kindest things we can do for ourselves is to take a step back from drinking.

Whether you’re already on an alcohol-free journey, whether you’re starting off, or whether you just want to take a break, here are some tips to help you through the month!

1. Plan ahead! Either let people know in advance that you won’t be drinking, or be prepared with what you’re going to tell them if they offer you a drink/ask questions. You don’t owe anyone an explanation that you’re not ready to share, but having a response rehearsed in advance can take the pressure off in social situations.

2. Stock up on alcohol-free drinks! It makes a world of a difference to have fun drinks to sip on that still make you feel included. 

3. Get comfortable with being uncomfortable! If you’ve grown accustomed to taking the edge off with booze, it can be an adjustment to sit with the emotions we’re used to numbing. And that’s okay! There’s a lot of power & strength that comes with feeling our feelings. And tackling life sober forces us out of our comfort zone, which allows us to develop *real* confidence & bravery (instead of relying on liquid courage).

4. Focus on the benefits! Really soak in all the amazing things about being alcohol-free. How incredible does it feel to wake up without a hangover, remembering every detail of your night? How much better do you feel physically? How proud & accomplished do you feel?

5. Community! Having support through a change like this is so important. Ask a friend to be an accountability buddy, or lean on the sober community for support! There are so many of us here on sober Instagram that are ready to cheer you on, and so many other incredible resources available for you 🤍

Above all else, be kind to yourself this month and don’t beat yourself up if you find it challenging (I did dry Jan before I got sober and it was SO hard for me). Remember that ANY break from alcohol is beneficial - you don’t have to get it perfect, you just have to show up & try! I’m rooting for you ✨ #happiestsober

I was stuck in a cycle of shame about my drinking for years before I was ready to address it.

Sobriety once felt impossible for me. I couldn’t imagine that my life could ever feel as happy or as fun without alcohol. 

But I got sober and now from the other side of it, I see that THIS is how life is supposed to feel. It was hard at first, but sobriety has made my life better in every way. 

I know the idea of getting sober feels so scary. But isn’t it even scarier to imagine living this way forever? You deserve so much more than that.

Let this year be the year you finally give yourself the opportunity to discover the magic of a sober life 🤍✨ #happiestsober

The short term pleasure we get from drinking brings us long term suffering. The short term discomfort of not drinking brings us long term peace & happiness. 

Drinking is never worth the trade off. Sobriety always is. 🤍 #happiestsober

In case you haven’t heard, I’m hosting a sober trip to Costa Rica through @trovatrip and I want you to join me! 🥰

When I first got sober, one of the hardest things to wrap my head around was how I was ever going to travel without alcohol. 

Drinking was always the main activity of travelling for me. There were even times I missed out on sightseeing so I could go get drunk instead, which makes me so sad now to look back on.

Going on a trip sober for the first time can feel so scary and intimidating, and it can feel especially challenging if we’re travelling with drinkers.

That’s why I’m SO excited about this trip. Because what better way to travel as a sober person than with a group of like-minded people who are all staying sober together and who are all there to be fully present & soak in every single experience.

And if you feel nervous to travel sober, then the best part is that we’re all there to support each other along the way. 🫶🏻

What I’ve learned is that there’s an instant connection and an unspoken bond between sober people when they meet. So I have no doubt that we’re all going to leave with a group of lifelong sober friends. ❤️

The trip is this May & the full itinerary is at the link in my bio! Head there to reserve your spot (only a 25% deposit is needed to book!), and send me a DM if you have any questions! We’re going to have so much fun together and I can’t wait ✨ #happiestsober

Happy Friday sober & sober curious fam! Here’s your reminder as we’re heading into the first weekend of Dry January.

It’s so easy to feel tempted to drink when the weekend rolls around. That’s why it’s so important to keep returning back to our “why”.

You’re not here without good reason. If you’re feeling like you want to drink, remind yourself of all the reasons you DON’T want to drink, and let that be your anchor.

Here are just a few reasons I don’t want to drink this weekend (or ever again):
• I don’t want to wake up with a hangover.
• I much prefer waking up with all my memories instead of waking up with drunk regrets.
• I love not being scared to check my phone in the morning.
• Waking up sober makes me feel so proud of myself.
• I don’t want to put myself through the hangxiety & shame that drinking causes me.
• Sipping my morning coffee with peace of mind & presence brings me so much happiness.

And so. many. more.

Reflect on yours. Connect to them. Write them down in a note on your phone so you have them handy whenever you need to pull them up.

You’ve got this & it’s going to be so worth it! 💕 #happiestsober

Saturdays were one of the most challenging days of the week for me when I first got sober. But now I freakin love them and I get so excited for my sober weekends, because I know I don’t need to drink to have fun or to enjoy myself anymore. ✨

That came with time, so if you’re struggling with staying sober this weekend, please remember that it gets SO much easier. And those challenging days are beyond worth hanging in for.

Here are some other things to keep in mind as we head into Saturday night!

• Quitting drinking does not have to mean the death of your social life. You can still live a fun, rich, full social life without alcohol.
• If getting sober made you realize you don’t love going out that much, that’s okay too. Honour that!
• The buzz we get from alcohol is so fleeting. The suffering it brings us afterwards is not. 
• If other people are drinking around you, they’re probably too drunk to notice what you’re doing anyways. That makes it easier to drop your inhibitions and let loose too! No booze needed for that.
• You will literally never wake up in the morning and regret staying sober the night before.
• I can’t think of a worse feeling than hangxiety, and the great news is that it’s 100% avoidable.
• Staying sober (even when it’s uncomfortable) is the absolute best way to build confidence in ourselves.
• You only have to take it one day at a time.
• Keep remembering that tomorrow morning you will thank yourself for staying sober tonight. 
• Nothing beats waking up with the inner peace that comes from remembering everything you did last night. 

You’ve got this sober, sober curious, & dry Jan fam! Let’s stay sober together this weekend! 💕 #happiestsober
Literally never gets old. Happy hangover-free Sunday! 🤍✨ #happiestsober

Monday reminder as we start off our week that alcohol doesn’t actually help us cope with stress. All it does it exacerbate our stress & anxiety tomorrow when we have to face the aftermath of drinking.

If you’re having a stressful week, the absolute kindest thing you can do for yourself is to stay sober through it. It might be hard in the moment, but you’ll be so thankful tomorrow when you’re not dealing with a hangover on top of your problems.

If you need some ways to de-stress without booze, here are some ideas:
• Light some candles & pour yourself an alcohol-free drink
• Get outside in nature or go for a walk in your neighbourhood
• Call a friend to vent 
• Watch your favourite comfort show
• Treat yourself to some delicious food or your favourite dessert 
• Go for a drive and blast music
• Do something to pamper yourself, like getting a mani-pedi

Most importantly, remember that we can survive the discomfort of our stress. We don’t have to drink to get through it, and it will pass. 

Self-care on our bad days is deciding not to make today’s problems even worse tomorrow with alcohol 💕 #happiestsober
It feels so hard at first, but you are in the process of transforming your life (and yourself!) in the best possible way 💫 #happiestsober

Just dropping in with a reminder that there is no regression on this journey. There is no coming back from what you now know.

I remember realizing this in my first few months of sobriety. I imagined drinking again, and it sunk in that there was really no turning back. 

Sure, I could’ve technically made the decision to pick up a drink again. But I could never again pick up a drink with that same care-free, excited feeling I used to have when I drank. I knew too much.

I had learned too much about what alcohol does to our brains and to our bodies. I’d had too many realizations about my problematic relationship with alcohol. I finally had an understanding of how drinking was impacting my mental health.

So even if I tried to go back, it would never be the same. And as scary as that realization was, it was also kind of freeing. Because indecision is kind of exhausting. And there’s something to be said for closing the door completely rather than leaving it open a crack.

There’s no going back. We can only move forward. And that’s kind of beautiful thing. Because I didn’t know it at the time, but moving forward in sobriety meant moving towards a better life than drunk me could have ever imagined. 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

Mornings are my favourite time of day. They’re full of coffee & possibility. 🫶🏻

But when I was drinking, my mornings were often taken over by hangovers, dread, regrets, and anxiety. Getting to fully enjoy my mornings again now that I don’t drink is one of my favorite perks of being sober.

Drinking robbed me of my mornings for so long, and sobriety gave them back to me. Coffee cheers to that! ☺️ #happiestsober

A Friday afternoon spent with my one true love, coffee ☕️🫶🏻 (okay and also my sister who took this photo and will be very unimpressed if she’s not included on that one). 

Staring down an entire weekend of not drinking used to feel like Mt Everest to me. Fridays felt so empty and anti climactic without kicking off my weekend with wine.

Now I get so excited knowing I have an entire booze-free weekend ahead of me. A sober weekend means:
• I get to wake up clear-minded in the morning, remembering everything that happened the night before
• I don’t have to play detective on my actions or feel any guilt, shame, or anxiety about how drunk I got
• I won’t wake up feeling physically sick
• I won’t waste away the day with a hangover when I could be out there actually enjoying my life 

This is a precious, short life and the weekends are our free time to do what *we* want to do. I wasted so many of my weekends in a hungover shame spiral, feeling like shit both physically and mentally.

We all deserve better than that! If you’re struggling with the idea of staying sober this weekend, let that be your motivation. Give yourself the gift of your own time back, and use it for whatever you need. 

Whether what you need is a night out for mocktails with some friends, or more self care, or more downtime, or more time to be active, or more time to be creative - staying booze-free makes it all possible!

When we’re sober and clear-minded (and not hungover & reeling about what we drunkenly said last night), the world is our freakin oyster. 

It’s okay if it feels hard right now. You can survive hard. Being hungover is hard too, and I’ll choose the hard that comes with being sober any day. 

The trade off is so. beyond. worth. it. You’ve got this sober fam! #happiestsober

800 days of staying committed to the best decision I’ve ever made, no matter how hard it felt at times. 

In 800 days I’ve had happy days, sad days, celebrations, birthdays, holidays, first dates, breakups, trips, fights, parties, wins, losses, excitement, disappointment, good news, bad news, laughs, tears. 

All things that used to have me reaching for a drink, but in 800 days I’ve survived them all without a single drop of booze.

I’ve had days where all I wanted to do was down a bottle of wine. But I’ve had 800 whole mornings of waking up so grateful for the fact that I don’t do that anymore.

800 days started with a day 1 (actually, 4 day 1’s in my case). And you only get any amount of days under your belt by taking it one day at a time and deciding not to drink today. 

Until eventually you don’t even have to think about it anymore, because it’s just your life now & you’re so thankful that it is 🥰

It’s one of the hardest & best things I’ve ever done. Nothing has ever been more worth it ✨ 

PS: if you want to be part of a supportive community while you’re on this journey, join my new support group, the Happiest Sober Hub! Let’s all connect and cheer each other on while we get through the ups & downs and create our happy sober lives! ☺️ The link to signup is in my bio 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

If my math is right, I’ve had 115 hangover-free Sundays since then.

This is such a silly statement but I’m going to say it: reality tv really gives me a lot of clarity & perspective on my sobriety.

First - and I’ve shared this one before - watching people party on reality tv shows is like literally getting to watch the tape play forward. 

Sometimes when they start drinking and they all seem to be having so much fun, I feel a pang of sadness and I miss that excitement of pouring my first drink of the night.

But without fail, I get to watch as they all turn sloppy, get in fights, make bad decisions, and then have to face the consequences of them the next day. And watching that all play out is such a great reminder not to listen to my mind when it starts romanticizing alcohol.

But there’s another thing I’ve been noticing lately. In the show I’ve been watching, there have been so many cases where someone is accused of cheating on their significant other.

And without fail, the immediate response is “I didn’t do it.” But then: “well, I’m pretty sure I didn’t do it… But I blacked out that night so I don’t know for sure what did or didn’t happen.”

And it has me thinking: how freaking nice is it to ALWAYS know our own truth. To always know without a doubt what we did or didn’t do. 

I can’t think of anything worse than being accused of doing something, and not even being able to defend myself because I literally don’t know the answer to whether I did it or not.

It’s just another one of the endless reasons that life is so much better in sobriety. Not only can I trust myself and my actions, but when it comes down to it, I always know what my own truth is.

I never want to experience the feeling of not remembering my own actions (and the panic that can come along with that) ever again. 

Shoutout to Vanderpump Rules for the wonderful reminder of that fact 😆💃🏼 #happiestsober

Psst, you can keep going 😉✨

If you’re feeling the benefits and don’t see a reason to go back to alcohol, amazing!

If the month was harder than you anticipated and you really want to go back to drinking, then that right there is some really valuable information about your relationship with alcohol. And probably an indication that you should keep going. ♥️

Either way, I’m so proud of anyone who cut out or cut back on drinking this month. It doesn’t matter if you got it perfect. What matters is that you showed up and tried.

And have I mentioned that you can keep going? Highly recommend ☺️✨ #happiestsober

Happy Friday, sober fam! Here are some reminders as we head into an alcohol-free weekend 🤍✨

• Staying sober is the absolute kindest thing you can do for your future self.
• You will never, ever regret the decision not to drink (even if it feels challenging in the moment).
• You don’t need booze to have fun, to laugh, to let loose, to dance. Adjusting to doing these things without drinking takes some time, and that’s okay! 
• Skipping the hangover this weekend means you gain a lot of time back that would’ve been wasted. You can take advantage of that! Plan something fun, try a new hobby, get creative, or just let yourself relax!
• There’s nothing better than the inner peace of checking your phone in the morning and not having to worry about finding drunk texts on it.
• No one else’s opinion about your sobriety matters except your own. You’re doing this for you!
• You’re not missing out this weekend by not drinking. It’s the opposite! You get to be fully present & have crystal clear memories of everything. 
• Being on this journey is something to be so proud of. Own it ✨

I’m cheering you all on! Let’s stay sober together this weekend 💕 #happiestsober

You never have to put yourself through it again! Isn’t that such a happy thought?!

It’s crazy to me now that despite years of struggling with crippling hangxiety, cutting out booze never felt like a realistic solution when I was in it. 

Hangxiety just felt like something I had to deal with, because the alternative of getting sober was unthinkable to me. 

Alcohol was what made my life fun and happy. It’s what connected me to my friends. It’s what I had to look forward to on the weekends.

Beyond happy to report that I couldn’t have been more wrong. And living free from hangxiety has been one of my favourite perks of being sober 🥰

No matter how hard it could feel to stay sober in the early days, knowing I had a hangxiety-free morning waiting for me was my best motivator.

How good to finally know that all that morning-after suffering is completely avoidable. I don’t have to feel that way ever again.

I get to stay sober and then I get to wake up feeling thankful about that every morning. 

Happy Saturday, sober fam! ✨ #happiestsober
Ice cream over wine, forever and always 😆🫶🏻🍦 I hope you all treat yourself on this hangover-free Sunday! 🤍 #happiestsober

When I was drinking, I was really just going through the motions in life. 

More and more, any intentions and ambitions for my life started to take a backseat to drinking. 

When I was 24, I moved to Australia and spent a year abroad. When I made that decision to go, my intention was for it to be a year to explore and grow and push myself out of my comfort zone and get to know myself.

But instead my time there became completely centered around drinking. I partied more that year than I ever have in my life, and my mental health took a hit because of it. 

This photo was taken the other day on a trail near my family’s house. My sister asked me to go feed the birds with her, and though it’s usually a no from me in the winter (😆) I said yes because one of my 2023 intentions is to yes more often!

It’s little things like that in sobriety that are such a gift: being so deliberate and intentional with my decisions about how I want to show up each day.

Though I didn’t stay long because we know I’m not built for the cold 🥲, I was able to enjoy a nice walk with my sister, and I wasn’t mentally absent & in a huge rush to get back home because it was almost wine o’clock (which definitely would’ve been the case a few years ago).

Instead I was excited to get home and get cozy with a coffee and enjoy a night with my family. No alcohol needed.

Sobriety is really the freedom to choose. I can spend my time however I want, because I’m no longer chained to my love of wine & rushing through whatever I’m doing because I want to start drinking.

And on the flip side, if I want to have the laziest of Sundays with my coffee & whatever show I’m currently binging, I’m doing it because I *want* to have a slow and relaxing day. Not because I’m dying of a hangover and have no other choice. 

I can live according to the intentions I set now, and I can deliberately create whatever life I want for myself, and that’s all because alcohol is no longer a part of it 🤍 #happiestsober

We all deserve the inner peace that comes from a hangover-free weekend. No hangxiety. No guilt. No “what happened last night?” texts. 

Let’s give that gift to ourselves this weekend, sober fam! Even if it feels challenging, it’s beyond worth it every time. Happy Friday ✨ #happiestsober

A moment of sober sunday gratitude for the fact that:
• I remember everything I did last night 
• I didn’t wake up in a panic
• I wasn’t scared of what I might find on my phone this morning 
• last night I got myself home safely, took off my makeup, brushed my teeth, and got into bed
• I don’t need to panic order myself a hangover breakfast on Uber eats
• I can enjoy my coffee this morning with a clear conscience and without a headache or nausea
• I’m not wondering if anyone is mad at me or if I embarrassed myself last night 
• I don’t have to play detective on my actions or ask anyone else how the night ended
• I’m not in a hangxiety-fueled shame spiral
• I get to enjoy my Sunday however I want to because I’m not suffering the physical or mental consequences of alcohol 

After a decade of believing that getting drunk was worth it despite how much it wrecked me the next day, I’ll never stop being grateful when my happy & peaceful hangover-free Sundays roll around 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

Monday sober motivation 💕💕💕

Drinking does not help us in building our biggest and fullest lives. Being sober does. 

There was a time when imagining my life without alcohol was the most depressing thought ever. But the irony is that my drinking was completely
hindering me from focusing on what I actually wanted in my life. Because more and more, what I wanted was to just drink.

Sobriety gives us the clarity & focus & time & motivation & self-awareness to identify what we want in life and to go after it.

When we’re no longer constantly hungover, we’re ✨unstoppable✨ #happiestsober

You don’t have to be an alcoholic to decide that booze isn’t serving you. And if you’re questioning your relationship with alcohol, I think that deep down you already know your truth.

Getting honest with ourselves and re-evaluating our relationship with alcohol takes so much courage. And deciding to quit drinking is a scary & hard change to make. 

But we don’t have to wait until we hit rock bottom & our whole lives are falling apart before we feel justified in making it!

We can decide anywhere along the way that we want better for ourselves than a life full of drinking, hangovers, & regrets.

Making that decision is the best thing I’ve ever done 🤍✨ #happiestsober

The sober gratitude is hitting extra hard this morning after I went out last night to celebrate a sober friend’s 6 month milestone 🥰

Celebrate yourselves today for being on this journey!!! I’m celebrating all of you 🤍✨ #happiestsober

Last week my sister went to a cocktail bar in our neighbourhood and told me we need to go back on a Thursday because it was super lively and it was a ✨vibe✨.

So we made plans to go there tonight, and I feel nothing but genuine excitement for a fun night out drinking mocktails at a bar.  

There was a time where it would’ve felt SO beyond depressing to even imagine going out sober. If this was my early sobriety, the fact that I wasn’t going to be drinking would be taking up so much mental space for me today.

But now, it’s not even a thought. Because I’m living life for my experiences and not for the drinks.

I absolutely love knowing that I can find fun in going out sober and don’t need to rely on alcohol to feel it.

I can find fun in listening to music, doing my makeup, and getting dressed up.
I can find fun in getting out on the town.
I can find fun in being at a cool spot with a fun vibe.
I can find fun in being social with people I love spending time with.
I can find fun in sipping a drink that’s not alcohol.
I can let loose. I can laugh my ass off. I don’t need booze for any of it. 

If getting sober has made you realize that you mostly prefer staying in, then I love that for you and you should 100% own that & honor that! 🥰

But if you want to still be able to go out sober and have fun, I’m here to tell you that you freakin can. 💃🏼 

It might take a little time to get there (it did for me!) and it might look a little different (I don’t stay out as late as I used to!) but I LOVE being able to enjoy my sober nights out, and then bask in my hangover-free & regret-free mornings after. ☺️☕️

Sobriety gives me a balance that I could never find in my drinking days. And it’s such an amazing way to live ✨

Once we accept the fact that we can survive our own discomfort, there’s literally nothing we can’t do. How’s that for a sobriety perk? ✨ #happiestsober

For a decade I relied on alcohol to feel good, to have fun, to relax, to let loose, to connect with others, to bond with my friends, to date, to feel confident, to get out of my head, to ease my stress, to cope with bad days, to enjoy myself, to be “happy”.

But here’s the thing: as long as we’re relying on an external substance to be able to feel good, we will never be free. 

Living my life in the present moment, rather than counting down to the next time I could pour a glass of wine, is absolute freedom.

Being able to enjoy myself, my life, and whatever I’m doing that day, rather than alcohol being the thing that makes my day enjoyable, is absolute freedom. 

Finally getting rid of the constant feelings of anxiety, regret, and shame that always coexisted with my drinking? Absolute. Freedom. 

Alcohol weighed down my life for a decade, and sobriety set me free. 🤍✨ #happiestsober

Happy Saturday! ✨ Here are some reminders to get you through your sober weekend! 🫶🏻

- You do not need booze to have fun, to relax, to connect with others, or to let loose this weekend.

We can miss something sometimes and still not want it back. We can feel nostalgic for the past “good” times and still know it wasn’t healthy for us anymore. We can have sad moments & grieve alcohol while still knowing that overall our lives are way happier when we’re sober.

Something I talked about last night during my meeting with the freaking INCREDIBLE members of my happiest sober support group is how our “why” can change as time goes on. 

I think it’s such an amazing thing to witness our why evolve as we continue on with our sober lives.

What I’ve noticed is this: the decision to get sober often comes from a place of pain & suffering, while the decision to *stay* sober comes from a place of joy & gratitude. 

My main & most important why in my early days of sobriety was very simply: I couldn’t stand to keep feeling the way alcohol was making me feel. I couldn’t take the internal suffering anymore.

My why now is because I freaking LOVE being sober. I love my sober life. I love how I feel about myself now. I love remembering everything I do. I love being present for every moment in my life (like this dinner out with my family this weekend 🥰). 

And of course, one of my biggest why’s has become all the amazing, inspiring people in this community that I’ve been lucky enough to connect with, and I’m so freaking grateful for that & for all of you 🥲♥️

I’d love to hear your why in the comments today! Has it changed as time has gone on?!👇🏻✨ #happiestsober

Happy Friday, sober fam! We got a burst of hot weather in Toronto this week (unseasonably hot!) and I was pretty much in heaven soaking up some sunshine these past couple days. 

This summer will be my third sober summer. And this is the first time that the initial taste of warm weather hasn’t triggered me to want to drink whatsoever. 

My first two sober summers, it caught me off guard how much the change in weather made me fantasize about drinking at first. The warm weather rolled around and suddenly I was romanticizing the idea of wine on my balcony, drinks on patios, and getting day drunk by the pool.

But if there’s one thing I keep learning in my 2+ years of sobriety, it’s that you never know how great something can be without alcohol until you just let yourself find out. Even though that sometimes means pushing through some hard feelings.

The reward that’s waiting on the other side of those challenges is so much better than anything we could ever find in a bottle of booze. And there’s no better time to take advantage of the rewards of sobriety than on gorgeous sunny days.

The best is yet to come 💛

✨ sober saturday reminders ✨
- You get to define what “fun” means for you now. And it’s okay if it takes some time for you to discover exactly what that is!
- Your sobriety and your needs come first. If that means staying in this weekend for some extra self-care, embrace that!

- Even if you feel awkward or uncomfortable in social situations at first, feeling those feelings is exactly what’s going to help you develop *real* confidence long-term. The kind you can’t find in a bottle.

I went out last night to watch the hockey game. Had a fun night out, drank soda waters, left the bar at midnight, got ready for bed, and crawled into it sober. 

Waking up with all of my memories, a clear conscience, and total peace of mind is something to always feel grateful for.

A few years ago, I’d be waking up with horrendous anxiety and would be absolutely spiraling about the parts of the night I didn’t remember (and probably embarrassed about the parts I did remember). 

I’d be texting my sisters asking how the night ended, if I did anything bad, if anybody was mad at me. And regardless of what the answer was, I’d spend the rest of the day riddled with the guilt and shame and anxiety that always came after drinking for me. 

For the longest time I couldn’t imagine living without the thing that was causing me alllll that suffering. 

But wow life is so so so much better without it 🌞 happy hangover-free sunday, sober fam ☕️🤍 #happiestsober

Turns out problems are just so much easier to face when I’m not also in a shame spiral about my drinking. Who would’ve thought 😅

Months before I made the decision to get sober, I heard @milliegooch say on a podcast that if you saw a small fire in your kitchen, you wouldn’t wait until your whole house was in flames before you put it out. 

So why are we expected to do that when it comes to our drinking?

It was the biggest light bulb moment for me because there was no denying that when it came to my relationship with alcohol, my kitchen was most definitely on fire.

Why would I wait until my whole house was burning down & my life was in shambles before putting it out?

So often when someone quits drinking, it’s met with “but what happened?” or “you weren’t so bad!”.

And that could not be more besides the point. 

It’s so incredibly powerful & brave to recognize that something is problematic (or just isn’t working for us) and to make a change before it gets to that point.

You don’t have to hit rock bottom. You don’t have to let the whole house burn down. You can simply decide that you don’t want to keep going down this path and you don’t want to live like this anymore. 

I’ve learned that the cool thing about putting out a fire in the metaphorical kitchen is that you get to remodel & renovate it afterwards 😏 

Putting out that fire is the first step, and then you get to create a new, better, brighter, happier, and more fulfilling life. It’s the best thing I’ve ever done for myself 🤍 #happiestsober
Saving this tip to the grid! 📝 Writing everything down can be the most powerful tool for both present day you & future you 🤍 #happiestsober

When I was drinking, my excitement for anything I was doing was mostly about the drinking that would be involved.

The excitement I felt for socializing, traveling, parties, holidays, celebrations, weekends, etc. mostly came from the fact that I was excited to *drink* while doing those things.

Knowing that I now find joy & excitement out of just living is pretty much the best feeling ever. I get high off of life, authentic connections, and new experiences, and I wouldn’t trade that for an artificial buzz in a million years 🥰 #happiestsober

900 days sober today! 🥰🥳✨ I spent the day driving out of town with a sober friend to pick up her new puppy from a farm. 

Tomorrow I’m road tripping to New York with my sister to go to my cousin’s bachelorette party, sober.

A week from now I’ll be hosting my first sober trip in Costa Rica, travelling and exploring a new place with amazing other members of this community that I love so much. 

900 days has happened one day at a time. In the beginning, I couldn’t imagine how life would ever be as fun or happy or exciting without alcohol in it.

I wish I could go back in time and tell myself how wrong I was, and all the incredible things that were in store.

The decision to get sober transformed my life in every way possible and opened doors that my drunk self didn’t even know existed.

There have been lots and lots of challenges in these 900 days, too. There’s been tears, sadness, heartbreak, anger, grief, disappointment, and everything in between. Because hard times are literally a part of life.

But experiencing even the hard emotions with a sober, clear mind is so worth it for the trade off. Because experiencing all of our emotions all the time means we get to experience the full range of our good emotions even more strongly. And it’s a really beautiful thing. 

Lately I’ve been feeling immense gratitude for this community more than ever. I’m constantly moved & inspired by the people I’ve connected with by getting sober, and it literally brings tears to my eyes on a regular basis (my Happiest Sober Hub fam can confirm 😆).

So if you’re reading this I just want to send a ton of love your way, because I’m genuinely so grateful for every single person in this community. Connecting with all of you will forever be a life highlight for me 🫶🏻

Next stop, 1,000 days! 💃🏼✨ #happiestsober
One of the many takeaways after doing my first sober bachelorette this weekend and having a freakin blast 💅🏻✨ #happiestsober

When I quit drinking nearly 2 and a half years ago, I never would’ve dreamed I’d be here hosting a sober trip to Costa Rica today. But here I am. 🥰

When we find the courage to get sober and to change, life just rushes to support us and it bursts wide open for us in amazing ways. 

When I was drinking, life was constantly just more of the same mediocrity. Now it’s full of opportunities I never would’ve seen coming and so many joys I would’ve missed out on if I was drunk or hungover. 

Today is my first morning waking up in Costa Rica and I couldn’t be more excited for the week ahead. Follow along on my stories this week to see what we’re up to! ☀️ #happiestsober

Lil photo dump of some of our week in Costa Rica so far. 🥰 The best time, the BEST people. Already don’t want it to end 🫶🏻 

PS: photo 9 is us with mocktail shots that our server made for us last night after he tried to come over with a tray full of real shots and had to take them back 😅🤣 When he gave me mine he said “I think it’s cool this entire group doesn’t drink!” And I have to agree ☺️ #happiestsober

… now I chase waterfalls instead 😆 if you haven’t been following along on my stories, I just got back from the most incredible week in Costa Rica spent with the most amazing, courageous, inspiring, and fun group of sober people. 

I was a mixture of nerves and excitement heading into this trip, and even my high expectations were blown out of the water. 

There was something SO indescribable about traveling and being in the present moment for every single experience, with a group of people who were ALL doing the same. 

When sober people come together, there is an instant bond. When sober people travel together (especially a group of sober people who are meeting for the first time, who are pushing themselves out of their comfort zones, who are facing different fears together)? It is ACTUAL magic. ✨

I’ll never, ever stop being grateful for this experience. Still on cloud 9 about it 🥰

Head to the link in my bio if you want to join me on my next sober trip (we’re going to Spain in September!) 💕 #happiestsober

It’s Mother’s Day so I’m sharing some of my mom’s words of wisdom from the last time she came on @happiestsoberpodcast 🩷

My mom hates when I make a fuss over her but she deserves all the credit in the world because as I always say, I genuinely wouldn’t have gotten sober when I did if I didn’t have her as a sober role model & as my support system. 

A big Happy Mother’s Day to all the moms out there and especially to all the sober ones! I can tell you from experience that your kids are the absolute luckiest to have a sober mom 🥰 #happiestsober

One of the hardest parts of getting sober for me was learning to feel all my feelings again.

I don’t think I was even aware how much I was numbing my feelings with alcohol until I removed it from my life. 

I literally remember thinking to myself in my early days: “I have so. many. feelings!” And it felt exhausting to feel them all without taking the edge off.

It takes so much strength to sit with our hard feelings, and to soberly face our fears. And anyone here doing that should be so so proud of themselves ♥️ 

When we numb our bad feelings, we numb our good ones too. And letting ourselves feel everything means we get to feel the *fullness* of all of our good emotions. And that’s the best gift in it all 🫶🏻✨ #happiestsober

ICYMI, I just came back from hosting my very first sober trip (we went to Costa Rica!).

I’ve been struggling to properly put into words how incredible & life changing this trip was. I fully expected for us all to connect on the trip, but I was not at all prepared for the bond we would all be leaving with after just one week together.

We had people book from different parts of the world. People in their 20s, 30s, 40s, and 50s. People with different stories and life experiences. But one incredibly powerful thing that connected us all.

This trip was about conquering fears. None of us went on this trip because we’re fearless. We went on this trip because we were facing fears together & pushing ourselves out of our comfort zones. And that’s always where the magic happens in life.

Traveling with other sober people is truly the best thing I’ve ever done. We came away with what I know are going to be lifelong friendships, we made incredible memories that we’re going to always remember, and we had so much fun (and shared SO many laughs) together.

I was both nervous and excited heading into this first trip, but now that I’ve experienced how incredible it is, I am pure excitement for the next one. If you’re nervous about traveling sober, this is the way to do it 🥰

I couldn’t be more excited and I’ll never stop being grateful for this opportunity to connect with you all & to make the best memories together! 💕 #happiestsober
Kicking booze to the curb will forever be the best decision I’ve ever made 🫶🏻✨ #happiestsober

When I quit drinking, I went through a very real grieving process. I had to grieve my love of drinking and all of the things I believed I got from alcohol. 

Little did I know, I was living a life of mediocrity as a drinker compared to what was waiting for me in sobriety. The best times of my life were waiting for me once I put down the bottle 🩷

PS: I passed my 2.5 year milestone while I was in Costa Rica! Woop! 🥳✨ #happiestsober

You deserve the inner peace and pride that comes from waking up after a sober night. Give yourself that gift this weekend. You’ll be so so so grateful to yourself when you wake up in the morning ♥️ #happiestsober

The fun that came from drinking cost me all my inner peace the next day. It was fleeting fun with an increasingly high price of suffering afterwards. 

I really used to believe alcohol enhanced the good times in my life. But now I know that all it ever did was take me right out of the present moment. I missed SO much because of drinking. 

You know what has enhanced the good moments in my life? Sobriety. 

I went to another concert last night (if you’ve been around here a while you might know that going to concerts sober is my absolute favourite thing to do).

I had so much fun. I was fully in the moment, taking in the experience. I was high off the vibes. 

And I got to wake up this morning with peace of mind, no regrets, and crystal clear memories of all of it. 

It was fun and happiness and excitement and joy without having to suffer for any of it after the fact. And that is how fun should be! We shouldn’t have to suffer & feel like shit in the name of “fun”. 

Sobriety isn’t boring or dull like I was scared it would be. It’s been the perfect balance between fun and peaceful. That balance is something I never could’ve dreamed of in my drinking days. 

In moments like these I feel so so so much gratitude for my sobriety. Now that I know how good it is, I’d never want to live any other way. Happy hangover-free Sunday 🩷 #happiestsober

Happy Monday, sober fam! If you need some sober inspo to kick off your week, here are just a few of the ways my life has gotten better in sobriety 👇🏻✨

1. I don’t wake up hungover & full of anxiety, shame, regret & dread anymore. Starting every day off with sober peace of mind is something I’ll always be grateful for.
2. I’ve made the most incredible connections in the sober community. The bond between sober people is unmatched!
3. I’ve grown more confident than I’ve ever been in my life. Relying on liquid courage prevents us from developing genuine confidence! Sobriety has forced the best kind of growth out of me.
4. I’ve gained so much time back in my life. Drinking and being hungover was a full time job!
5. Being sober & clear-minded 100% of the time means I’m always behaving in alignment with my morals. I’m no longer doing and saying things I regret and then feeling shitty about myself later. That wore down my self esteem over time, and being sober has built it back up. 
6. I’m able to not only show up better for myself, but for the people in my life, too. I’m kinder to myself, I can trust myself, and I like to believe I’m a better daughter, sister, and friend. I’ve also made it my mission to help others on their sober journeys & nothing has been more rewarding than that. 
7. I’ve rediscovered my sense of adventure and excitement in life. I don’t have a one track mind counting down to wine o’clock anymore, and I get so excited for the things I’m doing rather than just being excited to drink. 
8. I have full faith in my ability to push myself out of my comfort zone and do things that scare me. I lived a much smaller & more timid life in my drinking days. Doing something as hard as getting sober just shows us that we can do other hard things too!
9. I’m more fun now! My entire definition of fun used to be getting drunk (how boring is that?). With drinking out of the equation, I fill my time up with so many more fun things.
10.  I’m fully present for every moment of my life, and I’m creating memories that I’ll actually remember. Life is too short to drink it away and forget it!

Now I want to hear yours! Share with me in the comments 💖 #happiestsober

This weekend I went to the @taylorswift Eras Tour 🥹🩷

It was literally the night of my life and it just has me thinking about how the buzz I used to get from alcohol has absolutely NOTHING on the high we can get from life ✨

Before Taylor came out I was screaming crying and shaking uncontrollably (no shame in my fangirl game 🤣) and then I got to be up dancing and singing for the 3 and a half hours that she performed. 

No lining up for drinks before the concert, no worrying about keeping my buzz going during the show, and no having to miss songs to line up for drinks or the bathroom. 

Not only was I fully present for the entire thing, but the pure excitement and joy and high I felt came from ME! Not from a substance. 

Aside from the concert which was an obvious highlight, I got to have such an amazing weekend in New York. 

I had fun nights out sipping mocktails with my cousins and sisters. I got to meet up with a sober friend to celebrate his one year milestone (🎉). I went to my cousin’s bridal shower. I laughed a ton and made amazing memories that I’ll get to keep.

Have I mentioned that life is happiest this way? 🥰 #happiestsober
Hands down, no competition 🥰🙌🏻 #happiestsober

Most of the options we could choose between were alcohol related, so I chose that one because being sober is total BDE 💅🏻 #happiestsober

If there’s one thing I really needed to hear when I was struggling with my decision to get sober, it was this. 👆🏻

And that’s because I truly could not wrap my head around what my life would look like without alcohol in it.

I couldn’t fathom that life could ever be as fun or as happy or as exciting if I didn’t have drinking to look forward to. 

But I’ve discovered the absolute best truth, which is that my life is SO MUCH more happy and fun and fulfilling now that I’m sober.

I didn’t stop living when I got sober, which is what I was afraid of. Looking back, I realize I actually lived a much smaller and more timid life when I was drinking. Sobriety has made me so much more courageous, and it’s opened my life right up in the best possible ways.

I still go out all the time. I drink mocktails and have a blast. I’ve gone to so many concerts in the last year, I’ve lost count. I’ve made so many new connections and friendships with people all over the world. I’ve had the most incredible times travelling sober.  

I have fun all the time. I laugh all the time. I’m constantly inspired. I’m making the best memories that I actually remember. 

By the end of my drinking days, I relied solely on alcohol to have a good time. Now I find happiness in my actual life and I have a whole lot of fun living it.

Of course I still have challenges and bad days too, because that’s a part of life! But the bad days are a lot easier to get through when I’m not hungover and filled with shame & anxiety about my drinking.

If you’re afraid to make the decision to get sober, or if you’re in the early days and you’re struggling, I promise you it is so beyond worth it. You’re giving your future self the absolute BEST gift by being here. 

You do not have to stop getting out there and living life just because you don’t drink. Your best life is just waiting to begin ✨#happiestsober
Cheering you on, sober fam! Happy Saturday! 🫶🏻✨ #happiestsober

Madeline’s story serves as an inspiration to those who may be questioning their own relationship with alcohol, showing that self-awareness and the desire for personal growth can be powerful catalysts for positive change, even without hitting a traditional rock bottom.
