Drinking leaves us feeling SO much worse after the fact. It is never, ever worth it. 

We can survive anything life throws at us this week, and we don’t need to drink to get through any of it.

Your future self will ALWAYS be grateful that you didn’t drink today. 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

I’ve had some bad days and some lows this past week, so I thought I’d share these reminders (swipe through ➡️) for anyone who is going through it right now.

I’m grateful to be at a place in my sobriety now where drinking no longer crosses my mind as a coping mechanism (or as an option) when I have a hard day. But in my earlier sobriety, it felt SO challenging not to drink on my bad days. 

As difficult as it can be to navigate hard times in our lives without alcohol, I know without a doubt that if I was drinking to get through my bad days, things would feel so much messier.

How ironic that it’s sometimes the bad days that make me happiest to be sober ❤️

Proud of anyone who is soberly feeling the feels this week! It’s hard but it’s worth it 🫶🏻 

PS: I wrote this in my weekly newsletter a couple months ago. If you haven’t already, subscribe @ happiestsober.com for sober encouragement and inspo straight to your inbox! ✨ #happiestsober

Whether it was parties, holidays, vacations, flying, dating, breakups, birthdays, weddings, bachelorettes (the list goes on…) I struggled to believe that I could survive them sober, let alone actually enjoy myself without drinking in those scenarios.

But staying sober through them (despite the initial discomfort of it) allowed me to prove myself very wrong on that. 

It’s a great reminder that the thoughts that make us believe that we can’t do something are just that - thoughts! And just because we think or believe something about ourselves, does not make it true.

Sobriety gives us the opportunity to prove to ourselves just how capable we are of doing hard things. 

It’s allowed me to prove myself wrong time and time again, in the best possible ways 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

Happy Friday, sober fam! Here are some reminders as we head into the weekend: 

- Alcohol isn’t what bonds you to others. Showing up fully present & authentically yourself is how we create meaningful connection.
- Drinking may temporarily relieve our stress, but it exacerbates it tomorrow. If you’re coming off a stressful week, the best thing you can do for your mental health is stay sober!
- You don’t need alcohol to have fun this weekend. It’s a readjustment learning to have fun without drinking at first, and that’s okay! Reconnecting back to our real sense of fun & happiness (without relying on booze for it) is the BEST feeling. 
- Hangxiety is the absolute worst feeling and it’s totally AVOIDABLE. There’s nothing better than waking up on a weekend morning with a clear mind, a clear conscience, all your memories, and zero regrets.
- Staying sober is the absolute best gift you can give to your future self. You’ll thank yourself one day for doing this and for sticking it out even when it felt hard!
- Any challenges that come with staying sober in the evening will all be so worth it when you wake up hangover-free and SO proud of yourself in the morning. Play the tape forward. You can do this. 🫶🏻

Cheering you all on for an amazing alcohol-free weekend! ✨ #happiestsober

After so many mornings filled with shame about my drunk actions and about who I was, being able to wake up feeling proud of my sober self is the best feeling in the world ♥️

I went to my cousin’s wedding this weekend (more on that in my next post!) and it makes me so happy knowing I got to celebrate her on her special day in the best way possible because I’m sober.

No risk of blacking out, forgetting things, embarrassing myself, doing and saying things I regret, or god forbid drunkenly crying or getting in a fight. 

When we drink, we give up control. And I’d never want to give up control on such an important day, especially one that isn’t about me. I love being able to show up for the big days as the best version of me. 

It’s what the people I care about deserve, and it’s what I deserve, too.

Sobriety slowly but surely transformed how I feel about myself, with each morning that I got to wake up sober and proud. It’s the best thing I’ve ever done.

Let’s all give ourselves the gift of not drinking tonight together! Your future self will thank you ♥️ #happiestsober

Wedding weekend photo dump! ✨ 

I went to my third sober wedding over the weekend and had so much fun 🫶🏻

I drank mocktails at the rehearsal dinner the night before. I cried happy tears during the wedding ceremony. I drank club soda with lime during the cocktail hour and enjoyed the delicious food.

When we came back in for the toasts & dinner, they were handing out glasses of champagne. I asked if I could have a club soda in a flute glass to cheers with. 

The bartenders acted a bit thrown off and awkward about it because they had to grab an extra glass, but I didn’t mind 😆 we deserve the fancy glass, too!!! 🥂

Dessert was Ben & Jerry’s which was a whole entire vibe because ice cream is my favourite treat in the world. 

While I was enjoying my scoop, I overheard someone say they weren’t going to eat any because alcohol & ice cream wasn’t a good mix for their stomach. It made me extra happy to get to enjoy mine without having to worry about that🍦

Then I had a great time mingling, taking pics in the photo booth, and dancing until the very last song! 🪩✨

Weddings tend to be big drinking events, and for that reason it can be hard to imagine ever going to a wedding without drinking when we first get sober.

But I always find that those occasions that feel really hard & nerve-wracking & challenging are the exact ones that can make us feel the most gratitude for being sober.

I remember the whole entire thing. I didn’t get drunk and embarrass myself or cause any drama. I got to be fully present to celebrate my cousin who I love so much on her special day. I didn’t wake up with an ounce of anxiety or guilt about how the night went. 

I definitely have regrets over some of the weddings I went to in my drinking days, and I cannot say the same about any of the weddings I’ve been to sober.

That right there says it all ♥️ #happiestsober

The freedom. The mental clarity. The hangover-free, shame-free, hangxiety-free mornings. The crystal clear memories. The community. The inspiration. The extra time in my day. The authentic joy, fun, & laughs. The sober gratitude. 

Life is just so so so much better 2.5 years after cutting out booze, and I’d never, ever want to bring it back down by drinking ♥️✨ #happiestsober
Life’s not always perfect in sobriety, but it’s a hell of a lot better than it would be if I was drinking 🤍 #happiestsober

Swipe through ➡️ to see some of the hangxiety-fueled texts I sent in the last few years of my drinking days. 

If you need motivation to stay sober this weekend, let this be it. You do not want to have to send any texts like these in the morning. You deserve so much better than to put yourself through that 🤍

Knowing I never have to feel that way again fills me with so much relief & gratitude. I wouldn’t trade my calm, peaceful, hangover-free mornings for anything 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

Last night I went to a concert, which I’ve made no secret is my absolute favourite sober outing in the world 😆

It was a country concert (an artist I used to listen to in my early twenties but haven’t listened to in a while). 

We listened to some of his songs on the car ride over, and I realized that I’d forgotten how most country songs tend to focus on drinking. And hearing a few of his songs brought up some feelings for me. 

They had me romanticizing drinking a little bit. And they were also bringing back lots of memories and nostalgia for my drinking days, because I used to listen to those songs while partying. 

I let myself sit with those feelings, texted my mom, and went and reread my last post as a reminder (perfect timing, it came in handy!).

And then when I got to the concert and was surrounded by many extremely drunk people, it completely snapped me out of it. I felt instantly grateful to not be in their shoes. 

Those uncomfy feelings always get replaced with sober gratitude as long as we’re willing to hang in there through them ❤️

I used to beat myself up anytime I had a moment of romanticizing drinking, but now I know that fleeting moments like that can’t take away from my progress. 

I had a really fun time at the concert. I danced, sang, drank seltzer, and then got to drive home & crawl into bed sober at the end of the night. 

Waking up with sober peace of mind this morning after a concert that was so heavily focused on drinking is the best feeling in the world. 

Happy hangover-free Sunday, sober fam! Proud of us 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

PS: though he puts on an amazing show, if you’re feeling shaky about sobriety/sober concerts, I would *not* recommend going to a Luke Bryan concert anytime soon 😂❤️
Seriously though, being able to trust myself is the absolute best feeling 🥰❤️ #happiestsober

A little Friday sober gratitude reminder 🤍 I will never miss:
- Waking up on the couch (or in a weird place or in someone else’s bed) with a full face of makeup, a pounding head, and no recollection of how I got there
-Immediately scrolling my phone in a panic to check if I drunk texted anyone or posted on social media
-Having to ask someone else what happened last night
-Hearing embarrassing stories about myself
-Shame spiraling about how drunk I got 
-Feeling crippling anxiety about blacking out & forgetting things (and imagining the worst case scenario of what might have happened)
-Having to apologize for things I don’t remember doing
-Wasting the day away hungover & feeling like shit about myself

It’s easy to adjust to hangover-free mornings as more time passes, but in the early days of my sobriety, every single one of them felt like a freakin miracle because I wasn’t suffering like that anymore. 

I love reminding myself of how those mornings used to feel so I can connect back to SO MUCH gratitude for the fact that I stopped inflicting that suffering on myself. 

Let this be your reminder as we head into the weekend that drinking is not worth the consequences it brings! Sobriety gives you not only your mornings, but your life back. It’s the absolute best way to live ✨ #happiestsober

This weekend I went away on a little girls weekend to Niagara Falls. 💕

On Saturday night we went out to a country bar. I had SO much fun being out, dancing, and sipping soda waters all night. We stayed out until 1:30am and honestly I could’ve kept going 😆

If this was in my drinking days, I know exactly how the night (and morning) would’ve played out. 

I would’ve gotten too drunk at the bar, probably would’ve even forgotten the end of the night, and then would’ve woken up feeling anxious, stressed, panicked, low, embarrassed, and full of shame for drinking too much. 

But in those days, drinking was my entire definition of fun. I wouldn’t have been able to fathom spending that night at the bar without getting drunk. 

Now I get to have a ton of fun SOBER, and then wake up with total ease and peace of mind. I’m not missing out on anything - instead, I’m fully present for a fun night out and I’m just ditching all the internal suffering I used to inflict on myself with alcohol.

Forever grateful for the best decision I ever made 🩷 #happiestsober

I used to think of milestones as monthly or yearly soberversaries, and all of the “firsts” you do in the beginning of sobriety. But lately I’ve been noticing that even at 2 and a half years sober, they just keep coming!

One of the hardest things for me in my early sobriety was going home to hangout with my family and no longer drinking with my stepdad & sisters.

In those early days, I felt so left out when they would start drinking. It was always a bit of a sad moment for me. 

And it was SO important for me to always crack open an alcohol-free drink to cheers them with when they started drinking beers, because I desperately wanted to feel included and like I was still a part of all of it. 

One of the recent times I was home, I looked over and realized my sister had a half empty beer in front of her. And I didn’t! even! notice! that they had started drinking.

In my early days, I couldn’t imagine that it would ever be something I wouldn’t pay attention to, because it was SO high on my radar every time I was there. 

And instead that day I was just drinking my coffee, chatting, not paying attention. Because it’s not something I think about as much anymore or feel left out about.  Progress! 💕

This weekend I went away on a girls trip to Niagara Falls to celebrate my friend’s 30th birthday. There were 5 of us there sharing an Airbnb. When we arrived, I realized … I totally forgot to pack any alcohol-free drinks for myself. I didn’t even think about it!

Yes I love alcohol-free drinks and I ran out to grab a few seltzers to have on hand when I realized it, but the fact that I didn’t think to bring any just means that I wasn’t thinking or worrying about being the only sober one & what to drink in place of alcohol. It just wasn’t taking up any space in my head going into it! More progress 💖

The amazing thing about sobriety is that we get to continually evolve and grow, and it’s so important to acknowledge and celebrate our progress as we go ✨

Share a recent sober win with me in the comments! Nothing is too small! Let’s celebrate ourselves and each other today ☺️🫶🏻 #happiestsober

Little reminder that no one else’s opinion about whether your drinking is problematic matters. If drinking is having a negative impact on your life - no matter how “normal” or “okay” it may look to others from the outside - that is all that matters.

Only you know your own truth. Only you know your relationship with alcohol. Only you know the impact it’s having on your life and your mental health. 

No one else is living inside your head when you wake up full of anxiety and shame and regrets after drinking. They’re watching from the outside in a world where heavy drinking is very normalized.

Rather than asking if your drinking is a big enough problem for you to quit, ask yourself if drinking is bringing more positives or negatives into your life. Ask yourself how your drinking makes you feel about yourself. Ask yourself if your life & mental health would be better without it. 

We don’t need a permission slip from anybody else to be here. And if you’re asking yourself those questions, I think you already know your answer 🤍 #happiestsober

Oh hi July!!! ☀️ Summer is the perfect time to give yourself the gift of being hangover-free so you can enjoy every day to the fullest 💛

Whether you’re already on an alcohol-free journey, whether you’re starting off, or whether you just want to take a break, here are some tips to help you through the month!

1. Plan ahead! Either let people know in advance that you won’t be drinking, or be prepared with what you’re going to tell them if they offer you a drink/ask questions. You don’t owe anyone an explanation that you’re not ready to share, but having a response rehearsed in advance can take the pressure off in social situations.

2. Stock up on alcohol-free drinks! It makes a world of a difference to have fun drinks to sip on that still make you feel included 🍹

3. Get comfortable with being uncomfortable! If you’ve grown accustomed to taking the edge off with booze, it can be an adjustment to sit with all the emotions we’re used to numbing. And that’s okay! There’s a lot of power & strength that comes with feeling all our feelings. And tackling life sober forces us out of our comfort zone, which allows us to develop *real* confidence & bravery (instead of relying on liquid courage).

4. Focus on the benefits! Really soak in all the amazing things about being alcohol-free. How incredible does it feel to wake up without a hangover, remembering every detail of your night? How much better do you feel physically? How proud & accomplished do you feel?

5. Community! Having support through a change like this is so important. Ask a friend to be an accountability buddy, or lean on the sober community for support! There are so many of us here on sober Instagram that are ready to cheer you on, and so many other incredible resources available for you 🤍 You can also join my sober community @ the link in my bio ✨

Above all else, be kind to yourself this month and don’t beat yourself up if you find it challenging (I did dry Jan before I got sober and it was SO hard for me). Remember that ANY break from alcohol is beneficial - you don’t have to get it perfect, you just have to show up & try! I’m rooting for you 🫶🏻 #happiestsober #dryjuly

PSA: your life does not end when you get sober!

In the past 3 months: I’ve been to New York three times, I spent a week in Costa Rica (with a group of sober badasses who I will love forever 🫶🏻), I’ve gone away for two bachelorette parties (New York & Grand Bend!), been to two bridal showers, one wedding, 6 concerts, went away for a girls weekend to celebrate my friend’s 30th birthday, and went to Quebec for a friend’s Canada Day party. 

I have two more weekend getaways planned this month, and then in August another wedding and my thirtieth birthday 🥳

It has been a ✨busy✨ start to the summer (currently v sleep deprived lol), but I share this because I did allllll of those things without booze. And there was a time in my life where I genuinely would not have believed that was possible. 

Most of all, I wouldn’t have believed it was possible to actually *enjoy* myself and have fun doing any of those things without drinking. But I’m happy to report I’ve proved my old self very wrong on that.

Now in my third sober summer, I know that fun & good times & happiness don’t come from alcohol; they come from living life itself. 

From being sober, fully present, clear minded, connected, and being able to make amazing memories that I’ll actually remember. I wouldn’t want to be doing this summer any other way.

Life doesn’t end when you quit drinking. That’s when it really begins ☀️ #happiestsober

Summer stopped being cruel when I stopped spending it drunk & hungover 😉

Before I quit drinking, I genuinely never believed my life could ever be as fun again without alcohol in it. 

But pushing through those early hard & scary times, and then getting to discover just how wrong I was, has been the most rewarding experience of my life.

So far this summer has been the most busy, exciting, eventful summer I’ve ever had. And I haven’t missed alcohol one bit.

All the time & space & energy in my life that used to be taken up by drinking has been filled with sober adventures that I’ll never forget or regret.

Getting sober does not mean the good times in our lives end!!! 🗣️

PS: it’s my third sober summer. The first one was really challenging and the second one had its hard moments, too. If you’re struggling right now, I promise it gets easier with time, and you’ll be SO GRATEFUL to yourself one day for pushing through the hard ones 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

- Being sober inherently means feeling some discomfort sometimes, and that’s okay. Feeling all of our feelings is hard at first but we grow soooo much from it.

One thousand days sober today! 🥳 Pretty wild to wrap my head around ✨✨✨

Whenever I hit a new milestone, I always remember how Day 4 was such a massive deal for me in my first few attempts to quit drinking. I could hardly fathom double digits, let alone the 100s, let alone THIS!

For anyone who’s just starting out: this is just one thousand one-day-at-a-time’s 🤗💕

In the beginning, alcohol left behind a huge void that I seriously needed to grieve & then try to fill. 

And it has been pretty freaking cool to watch life fill that void with all sorts of incredible experiences, connections, and memories that NEVER could have happened if I was still drinking.

Life isn’t perfect now (always a work in progress and will always still have bad days!) but it’s so much better to be living my life intentionally, consciously, and fully present, rather than staying stuck in the same cycle of drinking too much and then hating myself for it after. 

In only my first month of sobriety, I created this account as an outlet to write about my sober journey, a place to find community, and a way to hopefully help/inspire others along the way.

What I didn’t anticipate was that this account would be my greatest accountability tool and would bring me to the absolute BEST people (all of you!) and I will forever be grateful for that 🥰

I’m so so so so so thankful to everyone who’s here. We’re in this together and I’m so proud of us 🫶🏻

Just a little reminder as we head into the weekend that sobriety does not have to be the death of your social life ✨

When I first quit drinking, I couldn’t imagine how I’d ever feel excited to go out again. I genuinely didn’t believe I’d have as much fun again now that socializing would no longer revolve around booze.

But we never know how great alcohol-free life can be until we give it a chance! 🫶🏻 Now I LOVE going out. I get so excited to patio hop in the summer. I love people watching and getting high off the vibes. 

And I get to leave all my nights out with mental clarity, peace of mind, and all my memories. There’s no better feeling than that 💃🏼 

Sober socializing took a lot of adjusting at first. I struggled with FOMO. I had to build up my sober confidence now that I no longer had a social lubricant. And my social battery was wayyyy lower for my first year+ of sobriety. 

But that was all just the adjustment process. This is a big change to make and change is a process. It takes time!

Maybe sobriety has made you realize you’re more introverted and you love quiet nights in, and that is so amazing too (I love both!).

But if you want to get sober and still be able to go out, have a blast, laugh, dance, and be the life of the party, your sobriety does not have to stop that 💖

The best part of sobriety is figuring out our own likes & dislikes and what sparks joy for us now. And as long as we’re following that, we can’t go wrong ☀️ 

Whatever you do this weekend, I hope you have an amazing AF one 💕 #happiestsober

Just a little Monday reminder in case the wine witch comes knocking this week 🙅🏼‍♀️

When we catch ourselves romanticizing drinking, it’s so important to remember that our idealized version of alcohol is not the truth of what it was for us!

We stopped drinking because it wasn’t working for us anymore. It either stopped being fun altogether, or even if the drinking part was still fun, the consequences of it far outweighed the pleasure we got from it. 

If alcohol was a positive thing in our lives, we wouldn’t have stopped drinking it! Simple as that. 

Getting sober is a big, hard, scary thing to do, and it would’ve been very easy to keep drinking if it wasn’t causing us so much suffering.

Every single one of us is here with very valid reasons, and that’s what we need to come back to when those inevitable, pesky doubts creep in. 

Trust the decision you made when you were actually living through the consequences of drinking, not the voice telling you it wasn’t “that bad”. If it wasn’t that bad, you wouldn’t be here doing this 🤍 #happiestsober

Saving this to the feed for anyone who struggles to be around drunk people in their sobriety right now ❤️

As much as it can be challenging, it is also a pretty great opportunity to feel super grateful about not being a drunk mess anymore 😆

Whenever I see others getting overly drunk around me, it fills me with gratitude & relief to know that I’m not doing that to myself anymore, and that I won’t be waking up with any of the shame & anxiety that always accompanied my hangovers. 

And of course, if sober gratitude isn’t where you’re at yet (or you just don’t want to be around drunk people, period!), then you are absolutely entitled to go home early or to skip the function altogether.

Your sobriety comes first, and that means having our own back on this journey no matter what that looks like ❤️ #happiestsober

This weekend I went to my fourth sober wedding and my first as maid of honor 🤍

What struck me the most about this one is how incapable I would’ve been of doing a good job on my maid of honor duties if I’d been drinking. 

It makes me SO happy to know that I was able to show up for my friend in the way that she deserved on her special day, and I know the alternative would’ve been something I’d regret forever.

I gave a toast, which I was so insanely nervous for, but I’m so glad I got to do it sober rather than relying on liquid courage in that moment ✨

And here’s the thing: I was able to party & celebrate my friend on her wedding *better* because of the fact that I was sober 🪩 

I danced until the very last song, and at one point I was only one of three people on the dance floor 😆💃🏼 #sobernotboring

Whereas the last wedding I was a bridesmaid in, I blacked out, and towards the end of the night I was passing out on my then-boyfriend’s shoulder while we ate cake 🫠 

It’s pretty clear which version of me was more fun, and it definitely wasn’t the drunk one who couldn’t even make it to the end of the night.

Weddings are big drinking events, and they can be some of the hardest events to get through in sobriety, especially in those early days. 

But knowing I’m fully present & my best self for that person’s special day makes me feel extra proud & grateful to be sober 🤍

And being the DD at the end of the night and then waking up with all my memories & no regrets or embarrassment or anxiety is the cherry on top of it all 🥰

Stay tuned for a podcast episode soon where I’ll chat about sober weddings & share some tips on getting through them! 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

I had a really stressful day yesterday, so I’m leaving this reminder here for anybody else who’s having a rough couple days 🫶🏻

I’m grateful that alcohol doesn’t cross my mind anymore when I’m having a hard day, but it used to feel so challenging not to drink to cope with my emotions when I was stressed out or upset.

As much as it can feel like alcohol gives us relief in the moment, drinking to take the edge off our stress always backfires. It leaves us feeling even more anxious, stressed, and low the next morning (and not to mention, hungover).

We can survive our emotions without drinking through them, even when it feels awful and uncomfortable. And when we stay sober through our bad days, we’re giving ourselves a fair chance for tomorrow to be a better day. Drinking guarantees that it won’t. 

Getting to the other side of a hard time without drinking through it is extremely empowering. That’s where we get to prove to ourselves just how strong we are & how capable we are of tackling life without booze. 

So proud of anyone who’s tackling life head on rather than drinking to numb & escape things. It takes a ton of courage, and that’s why even the bad days in sobriety are worth celebrating. Sometimes they’re the biggest sober win of all ♥️ #happiestsober

✨SOBER WEEKEND REMINDERS✨

Happy Friday, sober fam! Here are some reminders as we head into a sober weekend: 
- A hangover-free morning is the absolute best gift you can give to your future self
- Nobody’s opinion about your sobriety matters except your own (the people who give you a hard time about it are probably struggling with their own drinking, and you might even be the one who inspires them to make a change someday!)
- The buzz we’re all chasing when we want to drink is SO fleeting and it’s not worth ruining tomorrow over 
- You don’t have to hit a rock bottom to be justified in deciding to quit drinking (wanting to quit is enough!)
- Socializing without booze might feel uncomfortable & awkward at first, but it’s how we start to develop actual confidence in ourselves (which is so much better than any liquid courage we ever got from drinking)
- You can still go out sober, drink alcohol-free drinks, and have a blast (then you get to wake up with your dignity tomorrow, which is the best feeling ever)
- Sobriety is hard at first, but then life gets so much better & brighter than it ever could’ve been if you were still drinking
- No one has ever woken up hangover-free and regretted not drinking the night before
- Staying sober when you really want to drink is hard, but waking up full of regrets after a night of drinking is way harder 
- You’re so incredibly courageous for doing this, and you should celebrate yourself & feel proud of yourself every single day for that ☀️ 

You’re never alone on this journey - there’s a whole community here that is with you & rooting for you! Let’s stay sober together this weekend 💖💖💖 #happiestsober
Happy hangover-free Sunday ☺️☕️ #happiestsober

I had an amazing chat with @courtney___andersen on this week’s ep of @happiestsoberpodcast 💖

We chat all about Courtney’s story, her sober journey, getting sober in your twenties (she’s now 11 years sober after getting sober at 29!), motherhood & being a sober parent, and so much more!

You can listen now wherever you get your podcasts ✨ #happiestsober
It’s just so much better & more peaceful over here in sobriety 🤍 #happiestsober

It’s our dayyyyy!!! 🥳💖

There is nothing I love more than an opportunity to celebrate sobriety, and I will forever be shouting from the rooftops that absolutely anyone who is on a sober journey is SO incredibly amazing, brave, inspiring, courageous, and just all around the COOLEST ✨

Whether you’re on day 1 or day 10,000 or are just beginning to reevaluate the role alcohol plays in your life, I’m so proud of all of us and I’m celebrating us today! 🫶🏻

Share a recent sober win (or something that’s made you proud of yourself lately!) with me in the comments and let’s take today to remember what a big freakin deal we are for doing this!!! 👇🏻💕 #happiestsober

When I was drinking, my life basically revolved around my wine and going to the bar.

In sobriety, I go out for dinners, mocktails, concerts, comedy shows (which I did last night!), hikes, coffee dates, road trips, Taylor Swift dance parties, sober events, etc etc etc. I also have lots of quiet nights in because ✨balance✨ is another gift of sobriety. 

I’m traveling a ton this year and I’m doing it all sober. Last week while I was visiting Denver, I went to the Denver Art Museum and I thought to myself: if I was still drinking, there’s no chance in hell I’d be here right now 😆 

Before I got sober, I thought removing alcohol meant removing the fun from my life. But it really just opened up the time & space & energy to do way more fun & interesting things than sitting at a bar for hours on end, getting wasted, and having conversations I’d cringe and spiral about in the morning. 

Sobriety gives us the power to choose what we want to do with our time and what we want our lives to look like. For anyone in the early days, I promise you: the best is yet to come 💖 #happiestsober
Living my best life 🍦🫶🏻 #happiestsober

Wild that I used to think getting wasted was the most fun thing in the world, now I’m obsessed with the fact that I’m always clear-minded and fully present (and not ever about to drunkenly ruin my life 😆).

I’d never, ever want to go back to how it feels waking up after a night of drinking, not remembering what I did, and full of anxiety and regret and shame. 

Waking up with a clear conscience and crystal-clear memories every single morning is something I’ll never take for granted 🫶🏻 #happiestsober
Sober September thoughts 🤍 #happiestsober

Friday reminder to choose your hard 🩷 the struggles that come after drinking FAR outweigh the short term discomfort of staying sober. 

You’ve got this, sober fam! Let’s have an amazing alcohol-free weekend & let’s stay sober together✨

And just remember that if it feels hard, hanging in through that discomfort will make your hangover-free morning even MORE rewarding.

Sipping that morning coffee with total peace of mind and feeling so proud of yourself, so accomplished, & so grateful to be sober makes the challenges so worth it ☕️

Keep returning to your why & keep playing the tape forward! I’m rooting for you 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

Happy official start to fall, sober fam! ♥️🍂

The start of a new season can feel really challenging in sobriety. The change in weather can often be triggering (it can make us romanticize a cold beer on a patio in the summer, or mulled wine by a fire in the fall) and a new season brings with it a whole list of activities, events, holidays, etc. that we used to drink for. 

So if the start of this new season is making you romanticize the idea of drinking, swipe through ➡️ for some things to LOVE about being sober in the fall! 🥰

PS: I wrote this list in last week’s newsletter. If you want sober inspo like this straight to your inbox every week, click the link in my bio or head to happiestsober.com to subscribe! The next one comes out tomorrow 🫶🏻 #happiestsober
Coffee cheers to us, sober fam ☕️🥰🫶🏻 #happiestsober

I’ve been thinking a lot lately about how sobriety opens up the opportunity for us to find joy in the small, mundane moments in our lives.

In my drinking days, I searched for happiness in alcohol and in the BIG things. A big party night, a holiday, a trip. All things that revolved around drinking for me at the time.

Now in sobriety, I find joy in both the big and the small moments. I still love the big, exciting things (maybe even more so, because it’s the actual *thing* I’m excited about, not the alcohol associated with it).

But I can find happiness in the small, mundane moments now, too. Like my first sip of coffee in the morning. An afternoon walk. Catching up with friends over coffee. Listening to music. A great conversation. Getting lost in a book. A long drive on a sunny day. 

It’s pretty hard to enjoy small moments of gratitude in day-to-day life when you’re usually in an anxious shame spiral about your latest drunk actions. Or when you’re counting down to pouring a glass of wine. 

There is zero freedom in relying on an external substance to feel good. 

Happiness, joy, confidence, inspiration, connection, fulfillment - whatever it is we drank for - it doesn’t come from alcohol. It comes from OURSELVES. And we tap into the real thing by being willing to put the bottle down and discover that.

It’s hard and it takes time, but it’s so freaking worth it. 

So proud of everyone who’s here! Let’s have a great week 🩷 #happiestsober
Never stop celebrating your courage for being here 🫶🏻✨ #happiestsober

Sober gratitude came SO easily to me in my early days (hi pink cloud!) but the further I’ve gotten in my sobriety, the more it’s just become my normal life.

That’s why I think it’s important to be deliberate about sober gratitude! Staying connected to why I’m grateful to be sober keeps me connected to my “why” in sobriety 🫶🏻

Some things that make me so thankful to be sober: drinking my morning coffee with zero hangxiety. Being able to trust myself. Connections in the sober community. Being able to drive whenever I want (especially home after a night out ✨). Living with a clear mind & remembering everything I do & say.

Share something that’s recently made you feel grateful to be sober in the comments! 🩷👇🏻 #happiestsober

The “why” glow up we all deserve 🥰

My “why” in early sobriety was all about how miserable drinking made me. My “why” at this point in sobriety is because of how much better my life is because of it 🫶🏻 

For anyone in early sobriety, I know those early days can be so scary & challenging, and it can feel like life is always going to feel that way without alcohol. But that’s just how the early days feel! Not how sobriety feels when you stick with it.

If you keep hanging in there through the hard days, slowly but surely your life will transform in the best possible ways, and so will your “why” 💕 #happiestsober

Happy Sober Saturday! Here are some reminders to help you through the weekend:

• The short-term relief you might get from booze is not worth how terrible it’ll make you feel tomorrow.
• You will never regret a sober night.
• There’s no better feeling than waking up on a Sunday morning, checking your phone knowing there are no embarrassing drunk texts on it, and not having to ask anyone else what happened last night.
• Drunken “bonding” could never compare to soberly connecting with people in your life.
• The peace of mind that sobriety gives you is better than anything you could ever get from alcohol.
• You’re doing something many people will never have the courage to do.
• Hangxiety is the worst feeling ever and it is AVOIDABLE. You just have to stay sober tonight. 
• I’m so proud of you, and there is an entire community here rooting for you 💖

You’ve got this! Let’s make this a great sober weekend ✨ #happiestsober

It’s Sober October! ♥️🍂 Swipe through for some tips on staying sober this month, and remember that no matter how this month goes, you’re doing something so amazing for yourself by just being here & trying.

My drinking was destroying my mental health and actively making me suffer SO much, and yet I somehow still couldn’t imagine my life without it. 

At first the main benefit of quitting drinking was just that I’d removed the suffering it caused me (no more hangxiety or blackouts or regrets or shame or “what happened last night” texts 💃🏼)

But the best benefits came with time, and that is that I got to create a WAY more fulfilling life than drunk me ever could’ve imagined. 

I got to connect back to my real, authentic sense of happiness & purpose. I got to discover how much better life is with a present, clear mind. I got to make connections that don’t revolve around booze. I got to fall in love with mornings again.

Giving up my beloved wine once felt unthinkable. Now what’s unthinkable for me is giving up all the amazing things about sobriety for a fleeting buzz that made me suffer in the aftermath.

It was never worth it. Sobriety always is 🤍 #happiestsober
So glad I was hangover-free to enjoy this morning’s beauty emergency 🫶🏻 #happiestsober
Literally just the best news ever 🤍 #happiestsober #soberoctober

It’s the thanksgiving long weekend here in 🇨🇦 and it’s got me thinking about how there’s so much to be thankful for because of my sobriety. This weekend… 

• I had my family thanksgiving dinner with a clear mind. I got to celebrate my cousin getting engaged and I got to enjoy dinner and dessert and coffee and conversations and guitar playing (there’s always a post dinner jam sesh at my family gatherings✨). 

• I got to leave at the end of the night with all my memories and no embarrassment or cringe about drunk conversations with my relatives. 

• I got to wake up hangover-free on Sunday morning. I caught up with the people from my sober Costa Rica trip (who I love so freakin much) over zoom. We’re starting to plan a weekend reunion in the next couple of months and I couldn’t be more excited 🥰

• Then I enjoyed a relaxing, cozy, rainy afternoon. And then an impromptu drive with my sister to listen to music and look at the pretty fall leaves on the trees. Then my family and I watched the Barbie movie with pizza & ice cream. 

If I wasn’t sober, this weekend would’ve gone like this: drink too much wine at thanksgiving, wake up in a shame spiral, & waste away the day with a hangover and awful anxiety. 

It was a pretty quiet & low key weekend, but the small moments really are the big ones. And I wouldn’t have been present to enjoy any of it if I was still stuck on that hamster wheel of drinking & suffering. 

Every moment is always an opportunity for sober gratitude. Especially my first cup of coffee in the morning (if you watch my daily stories then you know 😉) so cheers to us today sober fam! 🤎 

No matter how you’re feeling today, I hope you take a moment to find a little bit of sober gratitude and to celebrate yourself for being here. It’s a big deal and it’s the kindest thing you’ll ever do for yourself. Proud of us 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

Yesterday ended up being a bit of a tough mental health day for me.

In my earlier sobriety, it was really hard to get through my bad days without reaching for alcohol to drown my sorrows. It felt at that time like this shift would never be possible, but now drinking genuinely doesn’t even cross my mind on my bad days.

Embarrassing to admit, but I *still* hadn’t unpacked and organized my room after moving over a month ago 😅 so last night I spent a few hours tackling it and made huge progress in clearing out my space. 

I put a journal and a pen on my nightstand and this morning I woke up early, meditated, and did some gratitude journaling. Because even in the tough times, being sober allows me to be intentional about self-care and about how I want to feel. 

The gift of sobriety is that we always get a *fresh* new day. If I was the old me yesterday, I would’ve drank to escape my emotions, and then woken up today feeling so! much! worse! It would’ve been a way to ensure that my bad day got extended and my emotions magnified.

Instead I get the opportunity to start fresh today & to take steps to make it a better day. We’re all always a work in progress, but I’m always extra thankful that I’m sober when I get to the other side of some hard emotions 🤍

PS: I wrote this caption and then opened Instagram and learned that today is #WorldMentalHealthDay (how fitting?!) so here’s your reminder that no matter what your relationship is like with alcohol, you don’t need to keep drinking if it’s ruining your mental health. 

Through life’s ups and downs, staying sober is the absolute best thing I’ve ever done for mine 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

I had the absolute pleasure of chatting with @sharon_hartley_ from Over the Influence on this week’s episode of @happiestsoberpodcast 💖

Sharon has been sober for over 5 years after she took a 90-day break from drinking and felt so great that she kept going. She’s so fun & hilarious and she speaks about sobriety with a joy and enthusiasm that is so contagious.

I absolutely LOVED this conversation & you can listen to it now wherever you get your podcasts 🫶🏻✨ #happiestsober

I’ve always had an intense fear of flying, and for my entire decade-long drinking career I relied on alcohol to calm my nerves before getting on a plane (ie, I’d get as much wine in me as possible before my flight).

When I got sober, flying was the hardest and scariest thing to imagine doing without alcohol. I genuinely didn’t believe I was capable of it. I even said to my mom when I first quit drinking: “can’t I just be a sober person who *only* drinks when they fly?” 😅

I’m posting this from the airport as I’m waiting to get on my ✨13th✨ sober flight (oh hi sober swifties!) and my 9th sober *solo* flight. A concept that would’ve seemed absolutely unthinkable to me a few years ago. 

Ditching liquid courage means giving ourselves a chance to develop our innate courage and conquer our fears. We don’t find courage from numbing our anxiety with alcohol - we find it by feeling scared and then still doing the thing despite that fear!

Flying still makes me nervous, but now that I’m facing my fear of flying rather than numbing it, it’s getting a little easier & calmer for me each time. 

So just a little reminder that when you first get sober, there are a lot of things that feel so impossible to ever imagine doing without alcohol. This was mine. But here I am doing it, and you can too ❤️ #happiestsober

Happy Friday sober fam! Just a little reminder as we head into the weekend that what you’re doing is a big deal and you deserve to treat yourself & enjoy life 🍝🍕☕️🧁🍦🫶🏻 (also, find someone who looks at you the way I look at a bowl of pasta) #happiestsober

Sober weekends were once so depressing for me. In early sobriety, I felt like I had nothing to look forward to if I wasn’t spending the weekend partying and getting wasted.

Then for a while I was determined to prove that I was ✨still fun✨ and that nothing had to change even though I was sober. I’d go out and drink mocktails every weekend, stay out late (even when I’d hit my limit), and not have to “miss out” on anything despite the fact that I wasn’t drinking anymore

Now I love my sober weekends because I can spend them ✨however the hell I want✨, all because I’m not going to be drunk or hungover. 

I can seize the day and get out in nature or I can hit a coffee shop or I can meet up with friends or I can take a little road trip or I can go to a concert or a comedy club or out for dinner or mocktails. I can choose to be productive or I can choose to relax or I can choose to be social.

I can now make decisions based on what I actually feel like doing rather than from a place of FOMO.

I can have a cozy movie night in (like I did last night) or I can dress up and go out for mocktails in the city (like I’m planning on doing tonight). Both are equally fun & exciting for me because I’m finding the balance I was never able to find in my drinking days. 

I know now that I’m never missing out as long as I’m doing what feels best for me, and sobriety has allowed me to own that.

However you’re spending your sober Saturday today, I hope it’s a great one 🧡 remember that there’s no right or wrong decisions - there’s only the right decisions for YOU 🫶🏻

Cheering you on for a hangover-free Sunday tomorrow! ☕️ #happiestsober

No hangxiety. No regrets from last night. No existential dread. No shame spirals. No “what happened last night?” texts. No hangover. Just sober peace of mind, sunshine, and lots of coffee ☕️🫶🏻

Happy Sunday, sober fam! This day is all ours 🧡 #happiestsober
The sense of pride & accomplishment that sobriety has given me is something I’ll never take for granted. I like myself so much better this way 💕 #happiestsober
It’s normal to romanticize alcohol sometimes, just make sure you’re romanticizing sobriety even more 🧡 #happiestsober

In my 1989 Taylor’s Version era 🩵🩵🩵🩵🩵

Sober Swifties, how excited are we for tonight?!? And which vault song are you most excited to hear?! Mine is between Now That We Don’t Talk & Is It Over Now because I love a breakup song 🥲💃🏼

My sober fam who aren’t swifties (if you’ve made it this far 😂), what’s an interest or hobby or ✨obsession✨ in sobriety that brings you as much joy as Taylor brings me?!👇🏻

Coffee cheers to my #soberswifties who will be waiting up until midnight to listen! So freakin exciteddddd 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

It’s Fri-yay (that’s Fri-Tay to my fellow #soberswifties who are currently in the year 1989 🩵) and what better way kick off our weekend than by celebrating ourselves & each other!!! ✨

Drop your number of alcohol-free days in the comments, and then reply to someone else’s comment to cheer them on! 

And remember, every single day under your belt is so massive and so worth celebrating. I challenge you not to include the word “only” in your day count! 

If you’re on day 1, or if you’ve slipped recently, we’re all here to support you! There’s no failure here 🫶🏻

If you don’t count days, drop a recent milestone or accomplishment that made you proud of yourself ✨

1,083 days for me today! 🥰 #happiestsober

This quote feels so important to share ♥️
(repost from @tawnymlara )

When you get dressed up cute on a Saturday night and head off for a night out, but then decide you actually don’t want to brave the snow (in October?!?) and instead have a cozy night in drinking seltzer in a fancy glass ✨

Last year on Halloween weekend, I dressed up and went to a house party (pic #3… karma is a cat 😆). This year I decided I didn’t want to dress up, and the only Halloween activity I’ll be doing is watching Hocus Pocus and maybe carving pumpkins 🎃 

Sobriety is the freedom to decide what we really feel like doing because our version of fun doesn’t revolve around alcohol anymore. We can celebrate (or not celebrate!) holidays however we choose 🫶🏻

One thing’s for sure, and that’s that my scariest Halloweens are the ones I can’t remember. Super grateful to not be adding blackouts, anxiety, shame, and regrets onto an already ~spooky~ season 🧡 #happiestsober

If you struggle with imposter syndrome in sobriety (if you find yourself wondering if your drinking was really “that bad”, or like maybe you were being dramatic by quitting drinking and you don’t actually belong in the sober community) then this week’s episode is for you 🫶🏻

You can listen now wherever you get your podcasts!✨ #happiestsober

Life’s so freaking short, and drinking makes us miss so much of it. 

When I look back on my 10 years of getting drunk and blacking out way too much, it makes me think of how many moments I missed out on. 

Drinking (or counting down to our next drink) makes us miss out on being in the present moment. Getting wasted & blacking out makes us miss out on creating memories we’ll remember. And being hungover makes us miss out on enjoying our mornings/days (and just our lives, for that matter).

Life is just too short for all of that, and I’m thankful I’m not wasting it by getting wasted anymore. 

I definitely would’ve missed taking this walk to look at the sunset if I’d been drinking my evening wine. And that would’ve been a damn shame.

There’s so much more freedom & life waiting to be lived on the other side of our decision to quit drinking 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

You don’t need to identify as an alcoholic to make the decision that booze is no longer serving you 🤍

I used to feel so conflicted about my relationship with alcohol (and what to do about it) because in my mind, the only justified reason to quit drinking was if you were an alcoholic. And that label never quite felt true for me. 

What gave me my ticket to freedom was learning that problematic drinking exists on a spectrum. You don’t have to hit an external rock bottom or fit a definition of what a problem drinker looks like to decide that drinking is no longer working for YOU. 

Throwing out the question “am I an alcoholic” and instead getting honest with myself about my relationship with alcohol & how it was impacting me is what empowered me to make the decision to get sober.

If you’re asking yourself whether your drinking is a problem, I think deep down you already know your answer ♥️

Getting honest with ourselves about our relationship with alcohol takes an unbelievable amount of courage. And making the decision to quit drinking is hard and it’s scary.

But we don’t have to wait until our whole lives are falling apart before we feel justified in doing it!

We can decide anywhere along the way that we want more for ourselves than a life full of drinking, hangovers, and regret. 

Making that decision is both the hardest and best thing I’ve ever done 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

I’m so so so excited to announce that my next sober group trip will be to Croatia in May 2024 😍🎉

I hosted my first sober trip to Costa Rica earlier this year, and it is not an exaggeration to say that it was the absolute best experience of my entire life. 

Yes Costa Rica is an amazing place, but what made the trip so incredible was the people. When a group of sober strangers push themselves out of their comfort zones to travel & face fears together, absolute magic happens. And that’s why I’m SO excited to do it again ✨

If you’re nervous to travel sober and you want to do it in a supportive environment with people who get it, or if you just want to travel & connect with a group of like-minded sober people (and have a wholeeee lot of fun together), join me!

The trip will be available to book next Friday November 10th, but you can head to the link in my bio now to view the full itinerary & all the deets!

I CAN’T WAIT 🥰🫶🏻 #happiestsober

THREE WHOLE YEARS IN MY SOBER ERA!!!!! 🥲🫶🏻✨

This caption feels so overwhelming to write because 3 feels like such a big number. Especially when I reflect on my early sobriety, when 4 consecutive days felt like a massive feat (if that’s where you’re at now, keep going!)

I feel like in this 3rd year, I’ve embraced my sobriety on a whole other level. I freaking LOVE being sober, more now than ever.

This year I had the most incredible experience of hosting my first sober group trip to Costa Rica. I’m planning my next one to Croatia. I started my community, the happiest sober hub, where I get to connect with the most incredible & brave & inspiring people.

And I released my very first episode of @happiestsoberpodcast on a total whim on my 2 year soberversary, which means it turns one year old today! 🥹

There are so many things that I imagined would be impossible to do (and enjoy) without drinking before I got sober. Like going to parties. Dancing. Celebrating. Dating. Traveling. Facing my fear of flying (I’ve done 13 sober flights and counting!). Getting through the best times & the worst times without booze. 

But when we choose to push past our discomfort rather than numbing it, absolute magic happens. We discover what we’re really capable of & we get to grow into the most courageous & best version of ourselves.

Super important to note that this reel is a *highlight* reel. Life is still always going to be life, and getting sober doesn’t make it perfect. 

As much as I’ve had lots of amazing times in these 3 years, I’ve had lots of really bad days too. But I know now that even when I’m struggling, my sobriety is the one constant in my life that anchors me. Staying sober through our hard times makes them so much more manageable.

I’ll never stop being grateful to myself for waking up 3 years ago and deciding that enough was enough. And if you’re here reading this - no matter where you’re at on your journey- I’m SO proud of you too. It takes an unbelievable amount of courage to be here.

I love this community so so so much & I’m so glad to be in this with all of you 🥹🥰 thanks for being along for the ride & inspiring me every single day 💕💕 #happiestsober

Just a lil reminder for anyone who needs to hear it that what you’re doing is such a big deal!!! I’m so incredibly proud & in awe of everyone who found the courage to be on this journey 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

✨SOBER SATURDAY REMINDERS✨

- Sober Saturday nights lead to hangover-free Sunday mornings. And there is NOTHING better than that!
- You decided to get sober for very valid & very powerful reasons. Stay connected to those this weekend 🫶🏻
- If you’re missing alcohol tonight, remember that it’s actually just your romanticized *idea* of alcohol that you miss. If it was really that fun & great, you never would’ve stopped!
- The buzz we get from drinking is fleeting. The regret and anxiety and suffering that comes afterwards is not. 
- The discomfort we might feel from staying sober is temporary, but the long term rewards are SO worth it. 
- You don’t need alcohol to have fun this weekend! Relearning how to have genuine fun again without drinking is one of the most rewarding & empowering parts of sobriety.
- You deserve to keep your memories of your weekend! Life’s too short for fuzzy memories & blackouts.
- Staying sober is the absolute best thing you can do for your future self, and you’re going to look back one day and be SO grateful 🩷

I hope you all have an amazing sober weekend! Cheering you on ✨ #happiestsober

And being hangover-free for it all isn’t too bad either 😉

But we can know that as long as we stay sober through any hard moment or any challenging time, we’re still SO much better off than we would be if we were drinking.

Just a reminder that if you’re struggling with your relationship with alcohol - no matter what your drinking or your life looks like from the outside - that right there is a valid reason to make a change.

The people around you might not understand it, and guess what, they don’t have to! You’re the only one waking up in your own head, feeling your own feelings, and dealing with the consequences of your drinking.

You’re the only one who knows what’s best for you. And if a little voice is telling you that there might be more to life than staying in the same cycle of drinking & suffering afterwards, then listen. It’ll be the best thing you ever do 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

The happiest thought & biggest relief for me in sobriety is this: I never, ever, ever have to feel that way again. 

That panicked wake up after a night of drinking.

The awful anxiety of not remembering what I said or did (or how I got home).

Scrolling my phone to check if I drunk texted anyone last night or drunkenly posted on social media. 

Having to ask someone else what happened last night or if anybody is mad at me. 

Cringing about the things I drunkenly overshared.

Wasting the day away in a hungover, anxious shame spiral.

Instead I get to wake up every single day with calm, sober peace of mind & all of my memories from the night before. 

So if you need something to be grateful for today: you never have to feel that way ever again.

What could be a happier thought than that? #happiestsober

✨lil photo dump from this weekend & some thoughts about sober connections ✨

Before I got sober, I genuinely believed alcohol was what made me bond & connect with others.  

Towards the end of my drinking days, it got to the point where I didn’t even feel that interested in hanging out with people if alcohol wasn’t going to be involved.

One of the hardest things to wrap my head around when I got sober was how in the hell I was going to feel as connected with others if we couldn’t bond over drinking anymore. And the grieving process for the role alcohol played in my relationships was so real. 

Now at 3 years sober, some of my best & deepest & favourite connections are with other sober people I’ve met in this community. There’s something about sober people (with one very powerful thing in common) bringing their open, authentic selves to the table that is just such an instant connector.

I used to come away from socializing with booze and cringe about my drunken over sharing. Now I come away from sober socializing feeling so recharged & connected & inspired & grateful & happy. 

(It wasn’t always that way though. It took a while for my social battery to return after I got sober!)

This weekend I got to meet up IRL with some of my members of the happiest sober hub and I’m still so in my feels about it. We got to bond even more in person, had so many laughs, and shut down the restaurant we were at on Saturday night because #sobernotboring ✨

All of this to say: if you’re newly sober and you’re worried about how you’re going to connect with others without alcohol, I promise that getting sober opens you up to WAY better connections than you could ever find over a bottle of wine.

Whether it’s with existing people in your life, or making new connections with sober people, *real* connection comes from showing up authentically
you & fully present.

It’s an adjustment at first, but I promise you it’s so so so worth it 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

Since today is Thanksgiving for those of you in the US (and therefore a big drinking day), I thought I’d give a little reminder for all the things you’ll have to be thankful for when you stay sober today.

You can be thankful to be present with whoever you’re celebrating today with.

If being around family members brings up some difficult emotions today, you can be thankful to be sober to process those emotions (rather than numbing, escaping, or possibly drunkenly responding in ways you’d regret).

You can be thankful for the ability to drive yourself home safely at the end of the night.

You can be thankful that you won’t wake up tomorrow with any anxiety, shame, or regrets because you drank too much and don’t remember what you did or said.

You can be thankful to be fully present to enjoy all the delicious food (drunk me only cared about wine, now dessert & coffee is my time to SHINE on holidays 🥰)

You can be thankful you won’t be cringing at drunkenly oversharing with family members. 

You can be thankful to wake up in the morning with a peaceful mind, all of your memories in tact, feeling so accomplished for staying sober, and feeling so proud of the person you are today. 

You can be thankful for another sober day under your belt, and for the knowing that you’re doing the absolute BEST thing for your future self. 

There’s so much to be thankful for in sobriety, and I promise that even if today feels hard, the payoff will SO outweigh any challenging moments you may have ♥️

Remember: stay connected to your why, play the tape forward, and don’t forget to celebrate yourself for what you’re doing. It’s a big deal!

You’ve got this sober fam! (Also today is my first American thanksgiving so if you’re celebrating today, we’re all in this together 😆) #happiestsober

What I was able to do in the last few days thanks to being sober:
- Drink seltzer while attempting to help make my mom’s chocolate cream pie recipe (an ✨adventure✨ for a clueless chef like me!)
- Celebrate American thanksgiving for the first time with my boyfriend’s family - fully present, clear minded, and knowing I’m showing up as the best (sober!) version of myself
- Enjoy a snowy chill Friday in drinking coffee, playing card games, watching Ted Lesso, sipping seltzer, and playing guitar (honestly just had the BEST day)
- Wake up early on Saturday and grab lunch & coffee in a cute town nearby
- Literally cry from laughing on Saturday night while playing games (sober!)
- Go out for hangover-free brunch on Sunday morning

What I didn’t have to deal with the last few days thanks to being sober:
- Worrying in advance about whether I’d get too drunk at Thanksgiving 
- The mental gymnastics of attempting to not get too drunk (but spending the night fixating on whether I could have another glass of wine)
- Waking up full of regrets, with blurry (or forgotten) memories, and feeling crippling anxiety about whether I embarrassed myself the night before
- Wasting away the weekend hungover & feeling like shit both mentally and physically, unable to enjoy myself or be present because I’m full of hangxiety and shame 

Drinking really does feel like a loss at first, but the truth is that we gain SO much more than we ever lose. All we’re really missing out on when we quit drinking (aside from a 20 minute fleeting buzz) is a whole lot of suffering. 

Even if this weekend was a challenge for you, I hope you’re able to identify a few things (or memories!) you were able to gain thanks to the fact that you didn’t drink. And then celebrate the hell out of those!

Choosing sobriety is the ultimate gain, even if you can’t see it yet 🫶🏻 #happiestsober

I don’t have drinking dreams very often, but this weekend I had a dream that I’d gone to a party and couldn’t remember it afterwards. It sent me into a panic in the dream: did I drink? Did I blackout? What happened that I don’t remember?

When I woke up and realized it was just a dream (THANK GOD), it was the best best best reminder of how relieved & thankful I am to be living my life sober.

Ironically the night I had this dream was the night after I celebrated thanksgiving sober, and it made me reflect on the horrible hangxiety I would’ve been feeling that morning if I still drank. 

I do not miss that feeling one bit, and I’m forever so grateful that I freed myself from that cycle. 

If you’re ever struggling with feeling like you’re missing out in sobriety, remind yourself of all the negatives you’re !!!lucky!!! to be missing out on.

That suffering was always avoidable, and we give ourselves the greatest gift ever when we realize we don’t have to keep living that way 🤍 #happiestsober

This week I took a scenic train ride through the Rockies to Glenwood Springs, CO and soaked in these gorgeous hot springs overlooking the river and the mountains.

Our train there left at 8am, and they of course serve booze on it. I was thinking about how the old me would’ve 100% been kicking off the day (ahem, morning) drinking already by that point. Trips were always justification for me to drink all day.

At one point during the ride, we went and sat on the lounge cart that had an observation deck. The woman next to me was drinking wine, and I was thinking about how grateful I was to be sober to take in the views.

Then I got to spend all evening relaxing in the hot springs and taking in the beautiful scenery. The old me would’ve been going back and forth to the bar the whole time I was there. But now I can’t imagine not wanting to be fully present for such a cool experience. 

When I first quit drinking, I thought going on trips would be so sad and depressing if I could no longer drink on them. But as it turns out, it’s been the complete opposite. 

The things I once thought would be the worst and hardest to do without alcohol are actually the very things that make me happiest to be sober 🤍

I’ve been reflecting over the past few days on my last holiday season before I quit drinking. Blacking out at both my work & family Christmas parties and feeling crippling anxiety and shame from it (which haunted me for MONTHS, btw).

It’s these memories that we have to hold onto tightly if we start to romanticize drinking over the holidays. They bring us back to the truth of our drinking, and they’re also powerful reminders for everything we have to be grateful for in sobriety. 

It’s okay to miss drinking this season, especially if it’s your first time doing the holidays sober. But don’t let those feelings disconnect you from your own truth about why you’re doing this. 

We can miss something and still know we’re SO much better off without it. 

And there is SO much to be grateful for when we’re choosing to celebrate the holidays with a clear, peaceful, present, sober mind 🤍 #happiestsober

A few thoughts on the sober holiday season for anyone who needs them 🤍💭 #happiestsober

Sober (holiday) weekend reminders:

• You don’t have to go to the party this weekend if you’re not feeling up for it! You’re allowed to put yourself first & say no ❤️
• You deserve to remember your weekend and to wake up without any shame or anxiety after getting too drunk (we’ve all been down that road too many times to count, and it led us HERE. There’s nothing back there for you except more of the same misery. Keep going!)
• Alcohol isn’t what connects you to people and you are just as much a part of the celebration no matter what’s in your glass 🥂 (*AF cheers*)
• You might feel some FOMO when you see people drinking around you, but you can turn that FOMO into JOMO by remembering all the suffering you’re missing out on by staying sober (it is the biggest relief to be free from that!)
• You don’t find confidence in a bottle. And even if you feel awkward socializing without booze right now, feeling those feelings means you’re in the process of building up your sober confidence!
• If the holidays are a difficult time of year for you, drinking will only make them harder. You deserve to process your emotions & find healthy coping mechanisms that won’t backfire tomorrow
• If the holidays are a happy time of year for you, alcohol won’t enhance your joy, it will take it away tomorrow! This is such an amazing season to get to be fully present for 🫶🏻
• Drinking brings short-term relief but long-term suffering. Sobriety can be hard in the moment but the rewards are so worth hanging in there for!
• It takes so much courage and strength and self-love to be doing what you’re doing. Don’t forget to celebrate yourself for that. 
• Waking up hangover-free & with peace of mind every morning is the best best best gift you can give to yourself this holiday season 🎁 

I’m SO proud of everyone who is tackling the holidays without booze this year. We’re all in this together and I’m cheering you on ✨ #happiestsober

Some mindset shifts for tackling the holidays sober 🤍

It’s okay if the holiday season feels hard without booze or if you’re not quite where you want to be yet on your sober journey. 

But just remember that going through these initial new & scary times (and staying sober through all the emotions that go along with that) is exactly what is allowing you to grow & transform.

You can lean into the messiness of it all and trust that it’s all part of the process and it’s going to be so worth it ✨ #happiestsober

When I imagined life without alcohol, I thought there was SO much I’d be missing out on.

But the irony is that alcohol is what actually made me miss out on my life. On so many memories. On being a person I could feel proud of. On so many days lost to hangovers & shame spirals.

The only thing I’ve lost out on by getting sober is a 20 minute fleeting buzz that was followed by SO much suffering. 

The natural highs & happiness that we get to discover in sobriety are so much better than anything alcohol could ever give us.

When I got sober I stopped missing out on my life, not the other way around ❤️ #happiestsober

It’s the first weekend of 2024! If you’re tackling it sober, here are some reminders 💖

- Staying sober this weekend will give you SO much time back and you get to spend it however you want (no more wasting away the mornings / hours / days hungover and swallowed up by shame & anxiety) 
- You get to redefine what your version of “fun” is without alcohol! Fun is not an objective thing and being sober does NOT make you boring 🩷
- I’m willing to bet we could alllllll name countless nights we regret thanks to alcohol. But you will never, ever, ever, ever regret the decision to stay sober 
- Emotions are meant to be felt, not numbed, and you are fully capable of sitting with whatever feelings might come up for you this weekend
- We gain SO much more than we ever lose when we decide to quit drinking. Make sure you’re practicing gratitude for what you’re gaining this weekend (and all the negatives you’re missing out on!)
- All that suffering drinking caused you? Great news! It is totally AVOIDABLE. All you have to do is not drink tonight 🥰
- Going against the status quo by not drinking is really brave and hard and it’s a really big deal, and you deserve to feel proud & celebrate yourself for that 🫶🏻
- If this weekend feels challenging, it doesn’t mean sober weekends will always feel challenging! It’s a big change and change is hard in the beginning. Trust that you’re in the process of growth and that it’s beyond worth it ✨
- Play the tape forward and remember that nothing is worth giving up the magic & relief & beauty & peace of waking up hangover-free ☕️

This week on the pod I’m chatting with @jenleehirst, an absolute powerhouse in the sober community!

Jen’s journey really speaks to the fact that problematic drinking is a progressive thing. She had to lose a lot before she was ready to quit drinking, but now she helps others by recovering out loud and her story is SO inspiring ✨

We also chat in this episode about how to sit with our uncomfortable emotions in sobriety & she shares some motivation for getting a consistent morning routine in place (always my goal! 😆).

You can listen now wherever you get your podcasts (or comment 60 and I’ll send you the link to listen! 💖) #happiestsober

You can miss something sometimes and still know it wasn’t good for you anymore 🤍 

No one decides to quit drinking without good reason, and you can trust the decision you made when you were actually feeling the consequences of your drinking more than the voice romanticizing it & telling you it wasn’t that bad.

 Stay connected to your why and keep going ✨✨✨ #happiestsober

I’m sick this weekend and we got a big snowstorm last night, so I’m throwing it back to summertime on a beautiful Colorado hike ☀️ and dropping in to remind you that you do not need alcohol to enjoy yourself this weekend. 

You don’t need to drink to have fun, to laugh, to dance, to celebrate, to relax, to unwind, to feel confident, to connect with others, or to cope with emotions. 

It might feel like you do right now because that’s what you’re accustomed to, but relearning how to navigate life & our emotions without booze is a process and it takes time 🫶🏻

And one of the best gifts of sobriety is reconnecting back to our inner joy & confidence & excitement for life and discovering just how capable we are of tackling life (through all its inevitable ups and downs) sober.

Let’s give ourselves the gift of a sober, present, clear-minded Saturday and a hangover-free, calm, peaceful Sunday. We’ll never regret it 🥰

Cheering you on, sober fam ✨ #happiestsober
